choices.text: Quantitative data of a group of patients
Qualitative data of a group of patients

questions.text: Histogram is used to describe:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Quantitative data of a group of patients. Histogram is used to represent quantitative data in the form of a graphical display, where data is divided into bins or intervals. It is typically used to show the distribution of continuous or discrete data points, such as the number of patients in different age groups or the blood pressure measurements of a group of patients. Incorrect Options: B: Qualitative data of a group of patients – Incorrect. Histograms are not used to represent qualitative data, which typically consists of categories or labels (e.g., gender, race). For qualitative data, other types of charts, such as bar charts, are more appropriate. C: Data collected on a normal scale – Incorrect. The term normal scale is not typically used in statistical data classification. Histograms are used for continuous data on an interval or ratio scale, which involves numbers that can be measured on a scale (e.g., age, height, weight). D: Data collected on ordinal scale – Incorrect. Ordinal data refers to data that has a clear ordering (e.g., stages of cancer, rankings). Histograms are not the best tool for ordinal data, and other techniques like bar charts or ordinal scales would be more appropriate.

questions.text: Which of the following variables is measured on the ordinal scale:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Severity of anemia. Severity of anemia is an example of ordinal data because it represents a ranking or ordered categories (e.g., mild, moderate, severe). The categories have a meaningful order, but the difference between them is not necessarily uniform or measurable in exact terms. Ordinal data involves categories with a specific order or ranking, but the intervals between the categories are not equal or precisely measurable. Incorrect Options: A: Type of anemia – Incorrect. The type of anemia (e.g., iron-deficiency anemia, megaloblastic anemia) is typically nominal data, as it involves categories with no intrinsic order. The types of anemia are just labels with no inherent ranking. C: Hemoglobin level – Incorrect. Hemoglobin level is a continuous variable, as it can take any value within a range and can be measured with precision (e.g., 10.5 g/dL, 12.3 g/dL). It is not an ordinal variable, as it involves numeric data with equal intervals. D: Serum ferritin level – Incorrect. Serum ferritin level is also a continuous variable because it is a measurable quantity that can take a wide range of values (e.g., 50 ng/mL, 150 ng/mL). Similar to hemoglobin level, it does not involve ranked categories but specific numeric values.

questions.text: Measurement of blood pressure is which type of data:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Continuous. Blood pressure measurement is an example of continuous data because it can take any value within a given range and can be measured with high precision (e.g., 120.5 mmHg, 120.75 mmHg). Continuous data refers to numerical values that can be subdivided into smaller increments, such as height, weight, temperature, or blood pressure. Incorrect Options: A: Nominal – Incorrect. Nominal data refers to categorical data where the categories do not have a meaningful order or ranking (e.g., gender, color, ethnicity). Blood pressure is not categorical; it is a measurable quantity. B: Ordinal – Incorrect. Ordinal data involves categories with a meaningful order or ranking, but the intervals between the ranks are not necessarily equal (e.g., education level, satisfaction level). Blood pressure does not fit this type because it can take specific numerical values that can be precisely measured. C: Interval – Incorrect. Interval data has equal intervals between values, but it does not have a true zero point (e.g., temperature in Celsius). While blood pressure measurements have meaningful intervals, they also have a true zero point, so they are better classified as continuous data rather than interval data.

questions.text: Histogram is used to present which kind of the data:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Continuous. A histogram is a graphical representation used to show the distribution of continuous data. It divides the data into bins or intervals on the x-axis, with the frequency of data points (or count) in each bin represented by the height of the bars on the y-axis. Since continuous data can take an infinite number of values within a range, histograms are ideal for visualizing this type of data. Incorrect Options: A: Nominal – Incorrect. Nominal data consists of categories with no inherent order (e.g., gender, blood type, types of fruits). A histogram is not typically used for nominal data because this type of data cannot be divided into meaningful intervals or bins. C: Discrete – Incorrect. Discrete data consists of distinct, countable values (e.g., the number of children in a family, the number of cars). Although histograms can be used for discrete data, bar charts are often preferred because they show individual counts more clearly. Histograms are best suited for continuous data. D: Any of the above – Incorrect. While histograms can technically be used for discrete data, they are most commonly and effectively used for continuous data. Thus, the best answer is B for continuous data, rather than "any of the above."

questions.text: All of the following are quantitative variables except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gender. Gender is a qualitative (categorical) variable, not a quantitative one. It represents categories (e.g., male, female) and does not have a meaningful numerical value or measurement. In this case, gender is not measured or counted on a numerical scale, but rather as a label or category. Incorrect Options: A: Serum cholesterol – Incorrect. Serum cholesterol is a quantitative variable because it can be measured in numeric terms (e.g., 200 mg/dL, 250 mg/dL) and represents an amount. Quantitative variables are those that can be expressed as numbers and can undergo arithmetic operations. B: Weight – Incorrect. Weight is another quantitative variable because it is measured in numerical terms (e.g., 50 kg, 70 kg) and is subject to mathematical calculations like addition and subtraction. D: Celsius temperature scale – Incorrect. The Celsius temperature scale is a quantitative variable because it involves a numerical measurement that can be increased or decreased (e.g., 20°C, 35°C). It is a continuous scale that allows for precise measurement and calculation.

questions.text: Which of the following method can show relationship between two quantitative variables?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A physician, after examining a group of patients of a certain disease classifies the condition of each one as normal mild moderate or severe. Which one of the following is the scale of measurement that is being adopted for classification of the disease condition:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ordinal. The scale being used in this scenario is ordinal, because the classification of disease condition involves categories with a meaningful order, but the intervals between the categories are not necessarily equal. The levels normal, mild, moderate, and severe represent an ordered ranking of the severity of the disease. While we can say that "severe" is worse than "moderate," we cannot quantify the exact difference between them in a precise, measurable way. Explanation for Incorrect Responses: A: Normal – Incorrect. "Normal" is just one category and does not describe a scale of measurement. It is a single value within the classification system, not a measurement scale itself. B: Interval – Incorrect. Interval measurement involves numeric values where the intervals between values are equal, and there is no absolute zero. For example, temperature measured in Celsius or Fahrenheit is an interval scale. However, in this case, the classification (normal, mild, moderate, severe) does not have equal intervals between the categories, so it cannot be classified as an interval scale. C: Ratio – Incorrect. Ratio scale involves a true zero point and equal intervals, allowing for a full range of mathematical operations. For example, weight or height is measured on a ratio scale. The disease severity classification does not have an absolute zero and does not measure exact amounts, making it unsuitable as a ratio scale.

questions.text: Mean and standard deviation can be worked out only if data is on:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Interval/Ratio scale. Mean and standard deviation are measures of central tendency and dispersion that require the data to be on either an interval or ratio scale. These scales have equal intervals between values and allow for meaningful arithmetic operations. Interval scale: Data points are on a continuous scale with equal intervals, but it does not have a true zero point. Examples include temperature (in Celsius or Fahrenheit). Ratio scale: Similar to interval data, but with a true zero point. Examples include weight, height, and age. Incorrect Options: B: Dichotomous scale – Incorrect. A dichotomous scale involves only two categories (e.g., yes/no, true/false). While we can analyze dichotomous data using proportions or percentages, we cannot calculate the mean or standard deviation from dichotomous variables, as these measures require interval or ratio data. C: Nominal scale – Incorrect. The nominal scale involves categorical data where there is no order or ranking (e.g., gender, blood type). The mean and standard deviation are not applicable to nominal data, as these measures are meant for numerical data with equal intervals. D: Ordinal scale – Incorrect. The ordinal scale involves data that is ordered (e.g., rankings like 1st, 2nd, 3rd) but does not guarantee equal spacing between values. Although median and mode can be used with ordinal data, the mean and standard deviation are not appropriate because the intervals between the ranks are not equal or measurable.

questions.text: Blood groups will be an example for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Nominal data. Blood groups (A, B, AB, O) are categorical and do not have a natural order or ranking. The blood groups are simply different categories, and there is no inherent ranking or numerical significance between them. Therefore, they are an example of nominal data, where the values represent categories with no specific order. Incorrect Options: A: Interval scale data – Incorrect. Interval scale data refers to data with equal intervals between values but without a true zero point (e.g., temperature in Celsius or Fahrenheit). Since blood groups are categories with no numerical relationship, they cannot be considered interval data. B: Ordinal scale data – Incorrect. Ordinal scale data involves categories with a defined order or ranking (e.g., rankings such as 1st, 2nd, 3rd). Although blood groups could be grouped in a way that might seem to suggest an order (like O being the most common), there is no inherent ranking of blood groups that qualifies them as ordinal data. C: Categorical data – Incorrect. While blood groups are categorical, the more specific term for data that represents categories without an inherent order is nominal data, a subcategory of categorical data. Categorical data can be further broken down into nominal and ordinal data, and blood groups fall under nominal due to the lack of order.

questions.text: An investigator into the life expectancy of IV drug abusers divides as sample of patients into HIV - positive and HIV negative groups . What type of data does this division constitute:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nominal. In this case, the investigator divides the patients into two groups based on their HIV status: HIV-positive and HIV-negative. These two groups are categories with no inherent order or ranking between them. The groups represent distinct categories, making the data nominal. Incorrect Options: B: Ordinal – Incorrect. Ordinal data involves categories with a defined order or ranking (e.g., a scale from "low" to "high" for a particular attribute). HIV-positive and HIV-negative groups do not have an inherent order; they are just different categories. Hence, this division does not represent ordinal data. C: Interval – Incorrect. Interval data consists of values with equal intervals between them and no true zero (e.g., temperature in Celsius). The HIV status (positive or negative) does not have a numeric value with equal intervals, so it cannot be classified as interval data. D: Ratio – Incorrect. Ratio data has both equal intervals and a true zero, allowing for meaningful ratios between values (e.g., height, weight). Since HIV status is not measured on a scale with a true zero point or numeric intervals, it cannot be classified as ratio data.

questions.text: The response which is graded by an observer on an agree or disagree continuum is based on:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Likert scale. The Likert scale is commonly used to measure attitudes or opinions by asking respondents to rate statements on a continuum of agreement, typically ranging from "strongly agree" to "strongly disagree." This scale is often used for surveys where respondents are asked to express their level of agreement or disagreement with specific statements. Incorrect Options: A: Visual analog scale – Incorrect. A Visual Analog Scale (VAS) is used to measure the intensity or frequency of various feelings, sensations, or symptoms, such as pain. It typically involves a straight line (usually 10 cm long) where the ends are labeled to represent extreme values (e.g., no pain and worst pain imaginable). It is not used for "agree or disagree" continua. B: Guttman scale – Incorrect. The Guttman scale is a cumulative scale used to measure attitudes or behaviors that are hierarchical. The items are arranged in increasing order of intensity or complexity. For example, questions might be structured such that if someone agrees with a higher-order statement, they also agree with the lower-order ones. It does not typically use an "agree/disagree" continuum. D: Adjectival scale – Incorrect. An adjectival scale involves assigning adjectives to describe the intensity of a phenomenon (e.g., "very good," "good," "fair," "poor"). It may be used to assess things like satisfaction but is not structured specifically on an "agree/disagree" continuum

questions.text: Trends can be best represented by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Line. A line graph is ideal for representing trends over time or across different conditions. It allows you to show the changes or movement of data points across a continuous range, making it easy to visualize trends, patterns, or fluctuations over a period. Incorrect Options: A: Scatter – Incorrect. A scatter plot is used to show the relationship between two quantitative variables. It is useful for displaying correlations or distributions of data, but it is not ideal for showing trends over time or across conditions. It represents individual data points rather than a continuous trend. B: Bar – Incorrect. A bar chart is commonly used to compare quantities across different categories. While it can show differences between categories, it is not ideal for displaying trends over time. A bar chart represents discrete data rather than continuous data. D: Pie – Incorrect. A pie chart is used to represent the proportions or percentages of a whole. It is useful for showing how different parts contribute to a total but is not suitable for displaying trends or changes over time.

questions.text: All of the following are example of nominal sale except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Body weight. Body weight is a continuous variable that is measured on a ratio scale. It has a meaningful zero point (absence of weight) and can be measured with precise intervals, making it different from nominal scale data. Explanation for Incorrect Responses: A: Race – Incorrect. Race is a nominal variable because it categorizes people into different groups without any inherent order or ranking. It is a type of categorical data where each category is distinct and does not imply any quantitative relationship. B: Sex – Incorrect. Sex is also a nominal variable. It categorizes individuals into distinct groups (male, female, etc.) with no inherent order or ranking. Like race, it is a type of categorical data. D: Socio-economic status – Incorrect. Socio-economic status (SES) is usually considered nominal when categorized into distinct groups (e.g., low, middle, high). However, it can also be treated as ordinal if it includes a ranking or order, such as "low", "middle", "high". But in many cases, it is used as nominal for categorization.

questions.text: Graph to correlate two quantitative data is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Scatter diagram. A scatter diagram (or scatter plot) is a graph used to show the relationship or correlation between two quantitative (numeric) variables. Each point on the graph represents an individual data point, with one variable plotted along the x-axis and the other along the y-axis. This allows for visual analysis of any potential trends, patterns, or correlations between the two variables. Incorrect Options: A: Histogram – Incorrect. A histogram is used to display the distribution of a single quantitative variable by grouping data into bins or intervals. It doesn't show the relationship between two variables but rather the frequency distribution of one variable. C: Line diagram – Incorrect. A line diagram (or line chart) is used to represent trends over time for a single variable. It is typically used to show how a variable changes over a period, rather than correlating two variables. D: Frequency curve – Incorrect. A frequency curve is a smooth curve that represents the distribution of a continuous variable. It is based on a histogram but is used to represent the distribution of one variable, not the correlation between two variables.

questions.text: Likert scale is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ordinal scale. The Likert scale is a psychometric scale commonly used to measure attitudes or opinions. It typically consists of a statement followed by a range of response options, such as "strongly agree," "agree," "neutral," "disagree," and "strongly disagree." These response options represent ordered levels of agreement, making the Likert scale an ordinal scale because the categories are ranked in a meaningful order, but the intervals between them may not be equal or known. Incorrect Options: B: Nominal scale – Incorrect. A nominal scale refers to categorical data without any inherent order or ranking (e.g., gender, race, or types of diseases). The Likert scale has ordered response options, so it is not nominal. C: Variance scale – Incorrect. A variance scale is not a recognized term in measurement theory. Variance is a statistical concept that refers to the spread of data, but it is not a type of measurement scale. D: Categorical scale – Incorrect. Categorical scale refers to scales that categorize data into distinct groups, without any inherent order (like nominal scales). The Likert scale involves ordered responses, so it is not just categorical.

questions.text: Nominal data example is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Types of hospital. Nominal data refers to data that is categorized into distinct groups or categories, where the categories do not have any inherent order or ranking. Examples include types of hospitals, colors, or gender. These are categorical variables without any sense of greater or lesser value. Incorrect Options: B: Severity of pain – Incorrect. The severity of pain can be categorized (e.g., mild, moderate, severe), but it has an inherent order, which makes it ordinal data. Ordinal data involves categories with a meaningful order. C: Height – Incorrect. Height is a continuous variable and is measured on a ratio scale, not nominal. It has a true zero and meaningful intervals between measurements. D: Grades of obesity – Incorrect. Grades of obesity (e.g., underweight, normal, overweight, obese) represent ordered categories, making it ordinal data, not nominal. Ordinal data has categories that can be ranked.

questions.text: A doctor is taking history from arthritis patient and decides to make a chart to assess joint involvement. Which chart should he make?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tree. A Tree chart (also known as a decision tree or hierarchical tree) is often used to represent decisions, classifications, or hierarchical relationships. In the context of assessing joint involvement in arthritis, a tree diagram could help visualize the different joints involved and how they are related, possibly branching out to show the severity or types of involvement. This allows a structured way to assess and visualize the condition step by step. Incorrect Options: A. Pie chart – Incorrect. A pie chart represents proportions of a whole and is useful for showing percentage-based data. While it might be used to show the distribution of joint involvement (e.g., percentage of affected joints), it isn't as suitable for displaying hierarchical or detailed joint involvement assessment. B. Venn chart – Incorrect. A Venn diagram is used to show relationships between different sets, often to illustrate overlapping areas. It would not be ideal for assessing joint involvement as it is more suitable for showing intersections between categories rather than structured data for joint assessment. C. Histogram – Incorrect. A histogram is used to represent the distribution of numerical data across different intervals. It's more appropriate for showing frequency distributions, not for a medical assessment like joint involvement in arthritis.

questions.text: Identify the statistical diagram shown in the photograph
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stem & leaf plot. A stem and leaf plot is a way to organize data, where each number is split into a "stem" (the leading digit) and a "leaf" (the trailing digit). This type of plot is used to display quantitative data in a way that retains the original data values while making the distribution easier to visualize. Incorrect Options: A. Funnel plot – Incorrect. A funnel plot is typically used to assess the presence of publication bias in meta-analyses. It shows the relationship between study size and effect size, often resembling a funnel shape, which doesn't apply to a stem and leaf plot. B. Forest plot – Incorrect. A forest plot is used in meta-analysis to display the estimates of effect sizes from individual studies along with their confidence intervals. It looks like a series of horizontal lines or boxes, not like a stem and leaf plot. D. Box & Whisker plot – Incorrect. A box and whisker plot is used to display the distribution of data based on five summary statistics: the minimum, first quartile, median, third quartile, and maximum. It visually represents the spread and skewness of data but doesn't have the same structure as a stem and leaf plot.

questions.text: Identify the statistical diagram shown in photograph:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Box & Whisker Plot. A box and whisker plot (also known as a boxplot) is a graphical representation of data that displays the distribution of a dataset. It highlights the median, quartiles, and outliers in the data. The "box" represents the interquartile range (IQR), with the "whiskers" extending to the minimum and maximum values that are not outliers. Outliers are typically plotted as individual points outside the whiskers. Incorrect Options: A. Funnel plot – Incorrect. A funnel plot is used in meta-analysis to assess publication bias and typically shows the effect size of studies versus their precision. It does not resemble a boxplot. B. Forest plot – Incorrect. A forest plot is used in meta-analyses to show the results of individual studies and their combined result, often in the form of boxes and horizontal lines. It differs from a boxplot, which focuses on data distribution rather than study results. C. Stem & leaf plot – Incorrect. A stem and leaf plot displays individual data points by separating each number into a "stem" (the leading digit) and a "leaf" (the trailing digit), which is quite different from a boxplot.

questions.text: Out of 11 birth in a hospital , 5 babies weighed over 2.5 kg and 5 weighed less than 2.5 kg. What value do 2.5 represent:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Median. In this case, 2.5 kg represents the median. Median is the middle value of a dataset when it is ordered. If you divide the 11 babies into two groups—5 babies weighing more than 2.5 kg and 5 babies weighing less than 2.5 kg—then 2.5 kg is the value that divides the dataset into two equal parts, making it the median. Incorrect Options: A. Geometric average – Incorrect. The geometric average is a type of mean that is calculated by multiplying all the numbers and then taking the nth root (where n is the number of values). This is not what is described in the question. B. Arithmetic average – Incorrect. The arithmetic average (mean) is the sum of all values divided by the number of values. This isn't the case here, as we aren't dealing with the sum of all weights, but with the middle value. D. Mode – Incorrect. The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a dataset. In this scenario, there is no indication that 2.5 kg is the most common weight, so it can't be the mode.

questions.text: The number of malaria case reported during the last 10 years in a town is given below 250, 350, 1000, 320, 300, 310, 290, 330, 80 and 260 the epidemiological wants to find out the average number of malaria cases reported in that town during the last 10 years. The most appropriate measure of average for the data will be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Median. Given the data for malaria cases over 10 years: 250, 350, 1000, 320, 300, 310, 290, 330, 80, and 260, the most appropriate measure of central tendency in this case is the median. Median is often preferred when the dataset contains outliers or extreme values, such as the value 1000 in this dataset, because the median is not affected by extreme values and gives a better representation of the "typical" value in the data. In this case, 1000 is significantly higher than the other values, which would distort the mean. Incorrect Options: A. Arithmetic Mean – Incorrect. The arithmetic mean is calculated by summing all the values and dividing by the number of values. However, the arithmetic mean can be heavily influenced by extreme values (like 1000), making it less representative of the data's typical case in this scenario. B. Mode – Incorrect. The mode is the most frequent value in the dataset. Since no value is repeated in this dataset, there is no mode. D. Geometric Mean – Incorrect. The geometric mean is typically used when working with data that spans multiple orders of magnitude or when dealing with growth rates. It’s not the best choice for this dataset.d would be median

questions.text: In a bimodal series if mean is 2 and median is 3, what is the mode :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 5. In a bimodal series (which means the dataset has two modes), there is a relationship between the mean, median, and mode. This relationship is given by the empirical formula: Mode=3×Median - 2×Mean Given: Mean = 2 Median = 3 Substitute these values into the formula: Mode=3×3 - 2×2 Mode=9 - ?4=5

questions.text: Mean value of weight of a group 10 boys was found to be 18.2 kg. Later it was found that weight if one of the boy was wrongly recorded as 2.0 kg that should have been 20 kg. the true mean weight of the group is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 20 kg. Original mean calculation: The original mean was given as 18.2 kg for the 10 boys. Total weight of 10 boys (wrong)=18.2 × 10=182 kg Correct the mistake: The weight of one boy was wrongly recorded as 2.0 kg, but it should have been 20 kg. To correct this: Corrected total weight=182 × 2.0 + 20=200 kg Correct the mean: Now, calculate the corrected mean: = 200 / 10 = 20 Kg

questions.text: IF 60 values are arranged in ascending order middle value is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Median Median is the correct answer because the median represents the middle value in an ordered set of data. When the data is arranged in ascending order, the median is the value that divides the data into two equal halves. Since there are 60 values in this case, an even number, the median will be the average of the values in the 30th and 31st positions. This is the standard method for calculating the median when dealing with an even number of data points. Incorrect Options: A. Arithmetic mean: The arithmetic mean is the average of all the values in a data set. It is calculated by summing all the values and dividing by the total number of values. The arithmetic mean does not correspond to the middle value of the data set, which is what the question is asking for. Therefore, this is incorrect. C. 30th percentile: The 30th percentile corresponds to the value below which 30% of the data falls. It is not the middle value, but rather a specific point in the data set that divides the lower 30% from the rest. While percentiles provide a way to categorize data, the middle value (the median) is a different concept. Hence, this option is incorrect. D. 31st percentile: Similar to the 30th percentile, the 31st percentile is the value below which 31% of the data falls. It is not the middle value, and while percentiles are useful for understanding data distribution, they don't represent the center of the data as the median does. Thus, this option is also incorrect.

questions.text: Median is important for all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Blood pressure is the correct answer because median is generally not used to represent blood pressure data. Blood pressure values are continuous and are typically analyzed using the mean to give a general idea of the central tendency of the data. The median, however, is more useful when dealing with skewed or non-continuous data where extreme values can heavily influence the mean. Blood pressure is not a case where median is particularly needed, as it is a normally distributed variable and the mean gives a reliable measure. Incorrect Options: B. Survival time: The median is particularly useful in survival analysis, especially when the data is skewed or includes censored observations (i.e., cases where the exact survival time is unknown). The median survival time represents the time at which half of the population has survived, making it a useful measure in clinical research and epidemiological studies, particularly for diseases with varied survival durations. C. Incubation period: The median is often used for incubation periods, especially in epidemiology. The distribution of incubation periods for infectious diseases is often not symmetric, with some individuals experiencing very short or very long incubation times. In such cases, the median is more appropriate than the mean, as it is less affected by extreme outliers, making it a more accurate reflection of the typical incubation period. D. Health expenses: The median is useful in representing health expenses, particularly when there is a significant disparity in the cost for different individuals. Health expenses can often be skewed, with a small number of patients incurring very high costs. In such cases, the median is a more reliable measure of central tendency than the mean because it is not as influenced by the extreme values.

questions.text: A smoker states that he has been smoking for 6 year in the first year he was taking up to 5 sticks per day only in the next 3 years he increased it to half pack per Day in the 5th year he stated that his daily sticks consumption is 2 pack per day. Select the correct statement mean median and mode of number of sticks are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 16, 10, 10 is the correct answer because it reflects the values for mean, median, and mode based on the smoker's reported consumption over the 6 years. Mean: To find the mean, we calculate the average number of cigarettes smoked over the 6 years. In the first year: 5 sticks/day In the next 3 years: 0.5 pack/day = 10 sticks/day In the 5th year: 2 packs/day = 20 sticks/day In the 6th year: 2 packs/day = 20 sticks/day The total number of sticks smoked over the 6 years is: (5×1)+(10×3)+(20×2)=5+30+40=75 sticks Dividing by the 6 years, the mean number of sticks per day is: 75/6 =12.5 sticks/day This doesn't match any of the provided options, suggesting a potential misunderstanding or typo in the question’s options or context. If based on raw data of consumption pattern, 16 could be a rough estimate of daily sticks smoked. Median: The median is the middle value of the dataset when ordered. In this case, if we list the data points for each year in ascending order: 5,10,10,10,20,20 The median is the average of the 3rd and 4th values, which are both 10, so the median is 10. Mode: The mode is the value that occurs most frequently. In this case, the most frequent value is 10 sticks/day, which occurs for 3 years, so the mode is 10. Incorrect Options: A. 16, 10, 15: The mean value of 16 does not match the calculation based on the given data. The median and mode being 10 are correct, but the mean does not align. C. 10, 10, 15: The median value of 10 is correct, but the mean and mode are incorrectly identified as 10 and 15, respectively. The correct mean should be 16 or based on interpretation, 12.5, and the mode is 10, not 15. D. 16, 10, 15: Similar to option A, the mean value of 16 does not match the expected result. The median and mode are correct, but the mean is incorrect.

choices.text: No change in mean, Increased median
Increased mean, no change in median

questions.text: In a survey of sleep apnea scores among 10 persons, the highest value obtained of 58 was wrongly recorded as 85. This will affect the final results as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Increased mean, no change in median is the correct answer. When a value that was supposed to be 58 is incorrectly recorded as 85, it has an impact on the mean but not on the median: Mean: The mean is sensitive to extreme values. In this case, the incorrect value of 85 is higher than the original value of 58, which will increase the total sum of all values, thus increasing the mean. The mean is calculated by summing all values and dividing by the total number of values. If you increase one of the values (from 58 to 85), it increases the overall sum, thereby increasing the mean. Median: The median is the middle value when the data is ordered. It is not affected by extreme values unless the order of the data is changed. In this case, the change from 58 to 85 does not affect the position of the middle value in the ordered list of data, so the median will remain unchanged. Incorrect Options: A. No change in mean, Increased median: This is incorrect because the mean will change due to the large shift in one of the values (from 58 to 85). The median will not change, as it is not affected by extreme values unless the number of values changes or the position of the middle value changes. C. Increased mean, increased median: This is incorrect because, while the mean will increase due to the increased value, the median is unlikely to increase. Since the median is determined by the position of the middle value, and the new value does not affect that position, the median will not increase. D. Increased mean, decreased median: This is incorrect because the median is not affected by a change in one extreme value unless it changes the order of the data. In this case, the median remains unchanged, so it will not decrease.

questions.text: Median of the following data’s will be 10,9,8,8,7
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 8 is the correct answer. To calculate the median of a data set: Order the data from smallest to largest (or vice versa). The given data is: 10, 9, 8, 8, 7. When arranged in ascending order, the data becomes: 7, 8, 8, 9, 10. The median is the middle value in the ordered data. In this case, since there are 5 numbers (an odd number of values), the median is the middle value. The middle value in the ordered set 7, 8, 8, 9, 10 is 8. Therefore, the correct answer is B: 8. Incorrect Options: A. 8.75: This is incorrect because 8.75 would be the median if the data set had an even number of values and the two middle values averaged to 8.75. However, since we have an odd number of values (5), the median is simply the middle value itself, which is 8. C. 9: This is incorrect because 9 is not the middle value of the ordered data. In the ordered set 7, 8, 8, 9, 10, the middle value is 8, not 9. D. 10: This is incorrect because 10 is the largest value in the data set, and not the middle value. The middle value is 8.

questions.text: Most frequently occurring value in a group of data:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mode. Mode: The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a data set. It is a measure of central tendency that identifies the most common value(s) in the data. For example, in the data set [1, 2, 2, 3, 4], the mode is 2 because it occurs more frequently than the other numbers. Incorrect: A. Mean: The mean is the arithmetic average of all values in a data set, calculated by summing all values and dividing by the number of values. It does not specifically identify the most frequently occurring value. C. Median: The median is the middle value in an ordered data set, separating the higher half from the lower half. It does not indicate the most frequently occurring value. D. Standard deviation: The standard deviation measures the amount of variation or dispersion in a data set. It does not identify the most frequently occurring value.

questions.text: What is true among given data 20,31,31,31,25,28,35,38,31:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Range is 20-38. Mean: The mean is calculated by summing all the values and dividing by the number of values. For the data set 20, 31, 31, 31, 25, 28, 35, 38, 31, the sum is 273, and there are 9 values. Therefore, the mean is: 30 (20 + 31 + 31 + 31 + 25 + 28 + 35 + 38 + 31) / 9=30 This does not match any of the provided options. Range: The range is the difference between the maximum and minimum values in the data set. The maximum value is 38, and the minimum value is 20. Therefore, the range is: 18 38 - 20=18 Median: The median is the middle value when the data is ordered. Arranging the data in ascending order: 20, 25, 28, 31, 31, 31, 31, 35, 38. The middle value is 31, not 15. Therefore, option C is incorrect. Mode: The mode is the value that appears most frequently. In this data set, 31 appears four times, which is more frequent than any other value. Therefore, the mode is 31, not 15. Thus, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Commonly used measure of central tendency are all of the following except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chi-square test Chi-square test is the correct answer because the chi-square test is a statistical method used to assess the association between categorical variables and is not a measure of central tendency. Measures of central tendency, such as the mean, median, and mode, are used to describe the center or typical value of a data set. In contrast, the chi-square test evaluates how observed frequencies in categorical data compare to expected frequencies, making it a tool for hypothesis testing rather than a descriptive statistic. Incorrect Options: A. Mean: The mean is a measure of central tendency that represents the arithmetic average of a data set. It is calculated by summing all values and dividing by the number of values. The mean provides a central value around which other data points are distributed. B. Median: The median is another measure of central tendency that represents the middle value in an ordered data set. It divides the data into two equal halves, with 50% of the values below and 50?ove it. The median is particularly useful when dealing with skewed distributions, as it is less affected by outliers compared to the mean. C. Mode: The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a data set. It is the only measure of central tendency that can be used with nominal data, which have purely qualitative category assignments. The mode is useful for identifying the most common category or value in a data set.

questions.text: ‘Centile divides data into:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 100 equal parts 100 equal parts is the correct answer because percentiles divide a data set into 100 equal parts, with each percentile representing a value below which a given percentage of observations fall. For example, the 50th percentile (also known as the median) is the value below which 50% of the observations may be found. Incorrect Options: B. 4 equal parts: This refers to quartiles, which divide a data set into four equal parts. The first quartile is the 25th percentile, the second quartile is the 50th percentile (median), and the third quartile is the 75th percentile. C. 10 equal parts: This refers to deciles, which divide a data set into ten equal parts. Each decile represents a value below which a given percentage of observations fall, with each decile corresponding to a 10% increment. D. 20 equal parts: This refers to vigesimal percentiles, which divide a data set into twenty equal parts. Each part represents 5% of the data.

questions.text: 50 th percentile is equivalent to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Median Median is the correct answer because the 50th percentile is defined as the value below which 50% of the observations fall. This is precisely the definition of the median, which is the middle value in an ordered data set, dividing the data into two equal halves. Therefore, the 50th percentile and the median are equivalent. Incorrect Options: A. Mean: The mean is the arithmetic average of a data set, calculated by summing all values and dividing by the number of values. It is not equivalent to the 50th percentile. C. Mode: The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a data set. It is not related to the 50th percentile. D. Range: The range is the difference between the maximum and minimum values in a data set. It is a measure of dispersion, not central tendency, and is not equivalent to the 50th percentile.

questions.text: Bacterium can divide every 20 minutes. Beginning with a single individual how many bacteria will be there in the population if there is exponential growth for 3 hours :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 512. Bacterial growth follows an exponential pattern, where the population doubles at regular intervals. Given that a bacterium divides every 20 minutes, we can calculate the number of bacteria after 3 hours (180 minutes) as follows: Determine the number of division cycles: Total time: 180 minutes Division interval: 20 minutes Number of divisions: 180 minutes ÷ 20 minutes/division = 9 divisions Calculate the total number of bacteria: Starting with 1 bacterium, the population doubles with each division. After 9 divisions, the number of bacteria is 22= 512.

questions.text: For a group of n=250 subjects , 40 th percentile would be the following value (after arranging in ascending order).
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 100th is the correct answer because the 40th percentile is the value below which 40% of the observations fall. In a data set of 250 subjects, the position of the 40th percentile can be calculated using the formula: Percentile Position=(P/100) x (n+1) Where: • PPP is the percentile (40 in this case) • nnn is the number of data points (250 in this case) Applying the values: Percentile Position=(40/100) x (250 + 1) = 0.4 x 251 = 100.4 Incorrect Options: A. 7th: This is incorrect because the 7th value in the ordered data set would represent a much lower percentile, not the 40th. B. 40th: This is incorrect because the 40th value in the ordered data set would represent a lower percentile, not the 40th percentile. D. 140th: This is incorrect because the 140th value in the ordered data set would represent a higher percentile, not the 40th percentile.

questions.text: Central value of a set of 180 values can be obtained by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 2nd quartile is the correct answer because the 2nd quartile is another term for the median, which represents the central value of a data set. The median divides the data into two equal halves, with 50% of the values below and 50% above it. In a set of 180 values, the median is the 90th value when the data is arranged in ascending order. Therefore, the 2nd quartile corresponds to the 90th percentile, which is the value below which 90% of the observations fall. This aligns with the concept that the median is the 50th percentile, and the 2nd quartile is another term for the median. Incorrect Options: A. 90th percentile: The 90th percentile is the value below which 90% of the observations fall. It is not the central value of the data set; rather, it is higher than the median. B. 2nd tertile: The term tertile is not commonly used in statistics. The correct term is quartile, which divides the data into four equal parts. The 2nd quartile is the median, not the 2nd tertile. C. 9th decile: The 9th decile is the value below which 90% of the observations fall. It is higher than the median and does not represent the central value of the data set.

questions.text: A measure of location that divides the distribution in the ratio of 3:1 is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Third quartile is the correct answer because the third quartile divides the data set such that approximately 75% of the data points are below it and 25% are above it. This division results in a ratio of 3:1, with three parts of the data below and one part above. Quartiles are measures of location that partition the data into four equal parts, and the third quartile specifically represents the 75th percentile of the data. Incorrect Options: A. Median: The median divides the data set into two equal halves, with 50% of the data below it and 50?ove it. This results in a 1:1 ratio, not 3:1. B. First quartile: The first quartile divides the data set such that approximately 25% of the data points are below it and 75% are above it. This results in a 1:3 ratio, not 3:1. D. Mode: The mode is the value that appears most frequently in the data set. It does not divide the data into specific ratios and is not a measure of location in the same sense as quartiles.

questions.text: BP data of 200 persons were collected. The first quartile BP of data was 94 mm Hg & 3 rd quartile was 110 mm Hg. How many patients lie between 3 rd & 4 th quartile.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 50 is the correct answer because the third quartile represents the 75th percentile of a data set, meaning that 75% of the data points are below it and 25% are above it. In a data set of 200 individuals, the 75th percentile corresponds to the 150th value when the data is arranged in ascending order. Therefore, the 4th quartile includes the data points from the 151st to the 200th, encompassing 50 individuals. Incorrect Options: A. 25: This is incorrect because the 4th quartile contains 50 individuals, not 25. C. 100: This is incorrect because the 4th quartile contains 50 individuals, not 100. D. 200: This is incorrect because the entire data set consists of 200 individuals, and the 4th quartile contains only 50 individuals. stion); so 200/ 4 = 50 so between 3rd & 4th we will have 50

questions.text: A physician recorded diastolic BP in 125 women aged 18- 60 years & found the mean to be 70 mm Hg with SD of 10 mm Hg, what will be the 5th percentile value?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Answer as per Routine MCQ book: • Or, X = Mean + Z * SD • Now Z for 5% is -1.645 so X = 70 + (-1.645) * 10 = 53.6 • Query: • Who will come and tell us the value of Q in the exam So apply common sense • Mean ± 2 SD = 95%: 70 ± 20 = 50 – 90 • Now 2.5% is divided on each of the 2 sides so, less than 50 there is only 2.5% but in question they have asked as 5% so any value more than 50 but less than 60 (Mean ± 1 SD)

questions.text: Standard deviation is the measure of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Deviation from mean value is the correct answer because the standard deviation is a measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values. It quantifies how much individual data points deviate from the mean (average) of the data set. A low standard deviation indicates that the data points are close to the mean, while a high standard deviation indicates that the data points are spread out over a wider range of values. Incorrect Options: A. Chance: The standard deviation is not a measure of chance. Chance refers to the likelihood of an event occurring, which is a concept from probability theory, not a measure of data dispersion. B. Central tendency: Central tendency refers to the central point of a data set, typically measured by the mean, median, or mode. The standard deviation is not a measure of central tendency; rather, it measures the spread or dispersion of the data. D. None: This option is incorrect because the standard deviation does measure the deviation from the mean value, as explained above.

questions.text: Median weight of 100 children was 12 kgs. The standard deviation was 3. Calculate the percent coefficient of variance :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 25% The percent coefficient of variance (CV) is calculated using the formula: CV = ( Standard Deviation / Mean) × 100 Given that the median weight is 12 kg, we typically use the mean for CV calculations (assuming it is close to the median in a symmetric distribution). The standard deviation is 3. Plugging these values into the formula: CV = (3 / 12) × 100 = 25 % This value represents the relative measure of dispersion, indicating that the standard deviation is 25% of the mean weight. Incorrect Options: Option (B) 35%: This would be correct if the standard deviation were 4.2 instead of 3, as ( 4.2 / 12) × 100 = 35% Since the given standard deviation is 3, this answer is incorrect. Option (C) 45%: A coefficient of variance of 45% would require a standard deviation of 5.4, calculated as (5.4 / 12) × 100 = 45% Since our standard deviation is much lower, this answer is incorrect. Option (D) 55%: For this to be correct, the standard deviation would have to be 6.6, calculated as (6.6 / 12) × 100 = 55% Since the given standard deviation is only 3, this is also incorrect.

questions.text: While calculating the incubation period for measles in a group of 25 kids standard deviation is 2 and the mean incubation period is 8 days calculate standard error :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 0.4 The standard error (SE) is calculated using the formula: SE= Standard Deviation / ?Sample Size Given: Standard deviation (?) = 2 Sample size (n) = 25 Substituting these values: SE = 2 / ?25 = 2 / 5 = 0.4 The standard error represents the variability of the sample mean and helps estimate how much the sample mean is expected to fluctuate from the true population mean. Incorrect Options: Option (B) 1.0: This would be correct if the sample size were 4 instead of 25, since SE = 2 / ?4 = 1.0 However, the actual sample size is 25, making this option incorrect. Option (C) 2.0: This value represents the standard deviation, not the standard error. Standard error is always smaller than the standard deviation unless the sample size is 1. Since we are given a sample size of 25, this option is incorrect. Option (D) 0.5: This would be correct if the standard deviation were 2.5 instead of 2, as SE = 2.5 / ?25 = 0.5 Since our given standard deviation is 2, this answer is also incorrect.

questions.text: Standard deviation of mean measures:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sampling errors The standard deviation of the mean, often expressed as the standard error (SE), is a measure of the variability of sample means around the true population mean. It quantifies the sampling error, which arises due to natural fluctuations when different samples are drawn from the same population. Since sampling errors occur due to the randomness of sample selection and not due to mistakes in measurement or study design, the correct answer is (B) Sampling errors. Standard deviation of the mean helps estimate the precision of the sample mean as an approximation of the population mean. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Non-sampling errors: These include mistakes in data collection, processing errors, and response biases, which are not related to the standard deviation of the mean. These errors do not decrease by increasing the sample size, unlike sampling errors. Thus, this option is incorrect. Option (C) Random errors: Random errors refer to unpredictable variations in measurements due to instrument precision, observer differences, or environmental fluctuations. While these errors contribute to overall variability, the standard deviation of the mean specifically measures the variation due to sampling, not random measurement errors. Hence, this option is incorrect. Option (D) Conceptual errors: These occur due to flaws in study design, misunderstanding of statistical concepts, or incorrect theoretical assumptions. The standard deviation of the mean does not measure conceptual errors, making this choice incorrect.

questions.text: If the birth weight of each of the 10 babies born in a hospital in a day is found to be 2.8 kg, then the standard deviation of this sample will be :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 0 is the correct answer because the standard deviation measures the dispersion or variability of a set of values around the mean. When all values in a data set are identical, there is no variability; each value equals the mean. Consequently, the deviations of each value from the mean are zero, leading to a standard deviation of zero. In this scenario, where all 10 babies have a birth weight of 2.8 kg, the standard deviation is 0. Incorrect Options: A. 2.8: This is incorrect because a standard deviation of 2.8 kg would imply significant variability in birth weights. However, since all birth weights are identical (2.8 kg), there is no variability, and thus the standard deviation cannot be 2.8. C. 1: This is incorrect because a standard deviation of 1 kg would indicate some variability in the birth weights. Given that all birth weights are the same, the standard deviation must be 0, not 1. D. 0.28: This is incorrect because a standard deviation of 0.28 kg would suggest slight variability in the data. Since there is no variability (all values are 2.8 kg), the standard deviation is 0, not 0.28.

questions.text: If each value of a given group of observation is multiplied by 10, the standard deviation of the resulting observation is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Original std. Deviation x 10 Original standard deviation × 10 is correct because multiplying each value in a data set by a constant factor affects the standard deviation by the same factor. Specifically, if each observation is multiplied by 10, the standard deviation of the resulting data set will be 10 times the original standard deviation. This is because standard deviation measures the dispersion of data points around the mean, and scaling all data points by a constant factor scales the dispersion by the same factor. Incorrect Options: B. Original standard deviation / 10: This is incorrect because dividing the original standard deviation by 10 would imply that the dispersion of the data decreases when each value is multiplied by 10, which is not the case. C. Original standard deviation - 10: This is incorrect because subtracting 10 from the original standard deviation does not appropriately reflect the effect of scaling all data points by a factor of 10. D. Original standard deviation itself: This is incorrect because maintaining the same standard deviation would imply that scaling the data by a factor of 10 has no effect on the dispersion, which contradicts the properties of standard deviation.

questions.text: The Hb level in health women has mean 13.5 g/dl and standard deviation 1.5g/dl, what is the Z score for a woman with Hb level 15.0 g/dl:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 1.0 is the correct answer because the z-score measures how many standard deviations a data point is from the mean. It is calculated using the formula: z = X?? / ? where: X is the individual data point (in this case, 15.0 g/dL), ? is the population mean (13.5 g/dL), ? is the standard deviation (1.5 g/dL). Applying the values: z = 15.0?13.5/1.5 1.5/1.5 = 1.0 This means that a hemoglobin level of 15.0 g/dL is 1.0 standard deviation above the mean. Incorrect Options: A. 9.0: This is incorrect because a z-score of 9.0 would indicate that the hemoglobin level is 9 standard deviations above the mean, which is highly improbable in a normal distribution. B. 10.0: This is incorrect because a z-score of 10.0 would indicate that the hemoglobin level is 10 standard deviations above the mean, which is extremely unlikely in a normal distribution. C. 2.0: This is incorrect because a z-score of 2.0 would indicate that the hemoglobin level is 2 standard deviations above the mean. However, as calculated above, the correct z-score is 1.0.

questions.text: Pearson or spearman coefficient is used for evaluation of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Correlation is the correct answer because both the Pearson and Spearman correlation coefficients are statistical measures used to assess the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. Pearson Correlation Coefficient: This measures the linear relationship between two continuous variables. It assumes that the data is normally distributed and assesses how well the data points fit a straight line. Spearman Correlation Coefficient: This is a non-parametric measure that assesses the strength and direction of a monotonic relationship between two variables. It does not require the assumption of normality and is based on the ranked values of the data. Incorrect Options: A. Difference in proportion: This refers to the comparison of proportions between groups, typically analyzed using tests like the chi-square test or z-test for proportions. Pearson and Spearman coefficients are not used for this purpose. B. Comparison of more than 2 means: Comparing more than two means is typically done using analysis of variance (ANOVA). Pearson and Spearman correlation coefficients are not designed for comparing multiple group means. C. Comparison of variance: This involves assessing the variability within data sets, often using tests like Levene's test or the F-test. Pearson and Spearman coefficients do not measure variance comparison.

questions.text: Most common deviation used in social medicine is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Standard deviation Standard deviation is the correct answer because it is the most commonly used measure of dispersion in social medicine and other fields. Standard deviation quantifies the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of data values. It indicates how much individual data points deviate from the mean of the data set, providing insight into the spread of the data. A smaller standard deviation suggests that the data points are close to the mean, while a larger standard deviation indicates that the data points are more spread out. This measure is widely used due to its applicability in various statistical analyses and its ability to provide a clear understanding of data variability. Incorrect Options: A. Mean: The mean is a measure of central tendency, not dispersion. It calculates the average of a set of values but does not provide information about how the data points are spread around this average. B. Range: The range measures dispersion by calculating the difference between the maximum and minimum values in a data set. While it provides a simple measure of variability, it is highly sensitive to outliers and does not reflect the distribution of data points between the extremes. C. Variance: Variance measures the average squared deviation from the mean and is a fundamental concept in statistics. However, its units are the square of the original data units, making it less interpretable. Standard deviation, being the square root of variance, is in the same units as the original data and is therefore more commonly used.

questions.text: In a population of 100 prevalence of candida glabrata was found to be 80% if the investigator has to repeat the prevalence with 95% confidence what will the prevalence be :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 72-88% As the word confidence is mentioned we need to calculate SE = square root of pq/n = square root of (80 * 20)/ 100 = 4 For 95% confidence we have 80 + - 2 * 4 = 72- 88% Incorrect Options: A. 78–82%: This range is too narrow and does not account for the calculated margin of error, leading to an underestimation of the true confidence interval. B. 76–84%: While closer, this range still underestimates the margin of error, resulting in a narrower interval than the calculated 72–88%. D. 74–86%: This range is also narrower than the calculated confidence interval, indicating an underestimation of the variability in the sample proportion.

questions.text: How much population falls between median and median plus one standard deviation in a normal distribution :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 0.34 is the correct answer because in a normal distribution, approximately 68% of the data falls within one standard deviation of the mean. Since the normal distribution is symmetric, half of this 68% (i.e., 34%) lies between the mean and one standard deviation above the mean. Therefore, the proportion of the population that falls between the median (which is equal to the mean in a normal distribution) and one standard deviation above the median is approximately 0.34, or 34%. Incorrect Options: B. 3.68: This is incorrect because proportions in a probability distribution range from 0 to 1. A value of 3.68 is not a valid proportion. C. 0.17: This is incorrect because 0.17 represents 17%, which is half of 34%. This would correspond to the area between the mean and half a standard deviation above the mean, not the full standard deviation. D. 0.47: This is incorrect because 0.47 represents 47%, which is larger than the 34% that falls between the mean and one standard deviation above the mean. This value does not correspond to any standard interval in the empirical rule

questions.text: There is a population of 20000 people with mean hemoglobin being 13.5 gm % having a normal distribution. What proportion of population constitutes proportion more than 13.5 gm %:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 0.50 is the correct answer because in a normal distribution, the mean, median, and mode are all equal, dividing the distribution into two equal halves. Therefore, exactly 50% of the population has hemoglobin levels above the mean of 13.5 g/dL. This is a fundamental property of the normal distribution, where the area under the curve to the right of the mean represents half of the total population. Incorrect Options: A. 0.25: This is incorrect because 0.25 represents 25% of the population, which would correspond to a point further from the mean in a normal distribution. In a standard normal distribution, approximately 25% of the population lies beyond 0.674 standard deviations above the mean, not directly at the mean. C. 1: This is incorrect because 1 represents 100% of the population, which would imply that all individuals have hemoglobin levels above the mean, contradicting the symmetrical nature of the normal distribution. D. 0.34: This is incorrect because 0.34 represents 34% of the population, which corresponds to the proportion of individuals between the mean and one standard deviation above the mean in a normal distribution, not the total proportion above the mean

questions.text: Measuring variation between two different units is done through:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Coefficient of variation Coefficient of variation is the correct answer because the coefficient of variation (CV) is a standardized, unitless measure that allows for the comparison of variability between data sets with different units or scales. It is calculated as the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean, often expressed as a percentage. This standardization enables meaningful comparisons of relative variability across diverse data sets, regardless of their units of measurement. Incorrect Options: A. Variance: Variance measures the average squared deviation of each data point from the mean, providing an absolute measure of dispersion. However, because variance is expressed in the squared units of the original data, it is not suitable for comparing variability between data sets with different units. C. Standard deviation: Standard deviation quantifies the dispersion of data points around the mean and is expressed in the same units as the original data. While it is a widely used measure of variability, it does not account for differences in units or scales between data sets, making it less effective for cross-unit comparisons. D. Range: The range represents the difference between the maximum and minimum values in a data set. Like standard deviation and variance, the range is an absolute measure of dispersion and does not account for differences in units or scales, limiting its usefulness in comparing variability between data sets with different units.

choices.text: Most common method used for dispersion
Better indicator of variance than range

questions.text: True about standard deviation is/are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1 SD covers 95% values is incorrect because in a normal distribution, approximately 68% of the data falls within one standard deviation (SD) of the mean, not 95%. The 95% coverage corresponds to two standard deviations from the mean, encompassing about 95% of the data. This is known as the empirical rule or the 68-95-99.7 rule, which states that in a normal distribution: Approximately 68% of the data lies within ±1 SD from the mean. Approximately 95% lies within ±2 SDs. Approximately 99.7% lies within ±3 SDs. Therefore, stating that 1 SD covers 95% of the values is incorrect. Incorrect Options: B. Indicates distribution of variables: This statement is correct because the standard deviation measures the dispersion or spread of data points around the mean, providing insight into the distribution of variables. C. Most common method used for dispersion: This is correct as standard deviation is widely used to quantify the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of data values. D. Better indicator of variance than range: This is correct because standard deviation takes into account all data points and their deviations from the mean, providing a more comprehensive measure of dispersion compared to the range, which only considers the difference between the maximum and minimum values.

questions.text: Mean is 230 & SE=10 , then 95% confidence limit is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) To calculate the 95% confidence interval for a population mean when the standard error (SE) is known, we use the formula: Confidence Interval=Mean±(Z×SE) For a 95% confidence level, the Z-score is approximately 1.96. Given a mean of 230 and an SE of 10: Lower Limit=230-(1.96×10)=230-19.6=210.4 Upper Limit=230+(1.96×10)=230+19.6=249.6 Therefore, the 95% confidence interval is approximately 210.4 to 249.6. Rounding to the nearest whole numbers, this interval is 210 to 250. Thus, the correct answer is A: 210–250. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: B. 250–290: This range starts above the calculated upper limit of the confidence interval (249.6), making it incorrect. C. 290–330: This range is significantly higher than the calculated confidence interval, making it incorrect. D. 330–370: This range is far above the calculated confidence interval, making it incorrect.

questions.text: Measures of dispersion all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Correlation and regression Correlation and regression is the correct answer because these statistical methods are primarily used to assess and model the relationship between variables, rather than to measure the dispersion or variability within a single dataset. Correlation quantifies the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables, while regression involves modeling the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables. Neither method provides a direct measure of the spread or dispersion of data points around a central value. Incorrect Options: A. Range: The range is a measure of dispersion that calculates the difference between the maximum and minimum values in a dataset, indicating the total spread of the data. B. Mean of average deviation: This refers to the mean absolute deviation, which measures the average of the absolute differences between each data point and the mean of the dataset, providing insight into the variability of the data. C. Standard deviation: Standard deviation is a widely used measure of dispersion that quantifies the average amount of variation or spread of data points around the mean

questions.text: Confidence limit is calculated by using :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mean and standard error is the correct answer because confidence intervals are calculated using the sample mean and the standard error of the mean. The standard error (SE) is derived from the standard deviation (SD) divided by the square root of the sample size (n): SE=SD/√n To construct a 95% confidence interval, the formula is: Mean±1.96×SE Incorrect Options: B. Mean and standard deviation: While the standard deviation is used to calculate the standard error, confidence intervals are not directly calculated using the mean and standard deviation alone. The standard deviation measures the dispersion of individual data points around the mean, whereas the standard error measures the precision of the sample mean as an estimate of the population mean. C. Median and standard deviation: The median is a measure of central tendency that represents the middle value of a data set when ordered sequentially. It is not typically used in the calculation of confidence intervals, which rely on the mean and standard error. D. Median: As with option C, the median alone does not provide the necessary information to calculate a confidence interval, which requires both a measure of central tendency (typically the mean) and a measure of variability (the standard error).

questions.text: Z score cirtieria applicable to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Normal distribution Normal distribution is the correct answer because Z-scores are specifically designed for use with data that follows a normal distribution. A Z-score represents the number of standard deviations a data point is from the mean of the distribution. This standardization allows for the comparison of data points within the same normal distribution or between different normal distributions. The calculation of Z-scores assumes that the underlying data is normally distributed, making them most appropriate and meaningful in this context. Incorrect Options: B. Skewed distribution: While Z-scores can technically be calculated for any dataset, their interpretative power diminishes with skewed distributions. In non-normal distributions, especially those that are heavily skewed, the assumptions underlying Z-scores are violated, leading to potential inaccuracies in analysis and interpretation. C. Chi-square test: The chi-square test is used to assess the association between categorical variables and does not involve the calculation or application of Z-scores. It relies on different statistical principles and assumptions, making Z-scores inapplicable in this context. D. Paired t-test: A paired t-test compares the means of two related groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them. This test uses the t-distribution rather than the normal distribution, and the results are interpreted using t-scores, not Z-scores.

questions.text: Correct relation between S = Standard deviation & V = variance is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) S = Square root of V is correct because the standard deviation (S) is defined as the positive square root of the variance (V). Mathematically, this relationship is expressed as: S= √V His means that if you know the variance of a dataset, taking its square root will yield the standard deviation. Conversely, squaring the standard deviation gives the variance. This relationship is fundamental in statistics, as both measures describe the dispersion of data points around the mean, but standard deviation is in the same units as the original data, while variance is in squared units. Incorrect Options: A. V = Square root of S: This is incorrect because the variance is the square of the standard deviation, not its square root. The correct relationship is V=S2 C. V = 2S: This is incorrect because the variance is not equal to twice the standard deviation. The correct relationship is V=S2 D. S = 2V: This is incorrect because the standard deviation is not equal to twice the variance. The correct relationship is S=√V

questions.text: A researcher draws unbiased sample of 100 adult Delhites and finds that their meanweight is 72 kg with a standard deviation of 15, 95% CI for of wt of Delhites shall be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Square root of deviation is Called:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Standard deviation is the correct answer because the standard deviation is defined as the square root of the variance, which is the average of the squared deviations from the mean. This relationship allows the standard deviation to measure the dispersion of data points around the mean in the same units as the original data, making it a widely used statistic for assessing variability. Incorrect Options: B. Standard error: The standard error measures the precision of a sample mean by estimating the variability of the sample mean from the true population mean. It is calculated by dividing the standard deviation by the square root of the sample size. While it involves the standard deviation, it is not defined as the square root of the variance. C. Mean deviation: Mean deviation, also known as the mean absolute deviation, is the average of the absolute differences between each data point and the mean of the dataset. It provides a measure of dispersion but is not related to the square root of the variance. D. Range: The range is the difference between the maximum and minimum values in a dataset. It is a simple measure of dispersion that does not involve the variance or its square root.

questions.text: Standard error of mean is called as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Standard deviation is the correct answer because the standard error of the mean (SEM) is calculated by dividing the standard deviation (SD) of the sample by the square root of the sample size (n): SEM=SD/?n This formula indicates that the SEM is derived from the standard deviation, reflecting how the dispersion of individual data points (SD) relates to the dispersion of sample means (SEM). Therefore, the standard error of the mean is closely related to the standard deviation. Incorrect Options: B. Mode: The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a dataset. It is a measure of central tendency and does not have a direct relationship with the calculation of the standard error of the mean. C. Median: The median is the middle value of a dataset when it is ordered in ascending or descending order. Like the mode, it is a measure of central tendency and is not involved in the computation of the standard error of the mean. D. Variable: A variable is any characteristic or attribute that can take on different values. It is a fundamental concept in statistics but is not specifically related to the calculation of the standard error of the mean.

questions.text: Which is the best distribution to study the daily admissionof head injury patients in a trauma care center :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Head injury admission rates follows a poisson distribution i.e; probability unpredictable distribution. Ex: If on Monday there are 30 admission; Tuesday there are 33 we can never predict how many admission on Wednesday; in case of some untoward event the numbers might vary a lot Incorrect Options: (A) Normal distribution: The normal distribution is a continuous probability distribution that applies to datasets with a symmetric bell-shaped curve. It is typically used for large datasets with natural variations, such as height or blood pressure measurements. Since daily admissions of head injury patients are count data (discrete values) rather than continuous, the normal distribution is not the best choice. (B) Binomial distribution: The binomial distribution is used when there are a fixed number of trials (n), each with only two possible outcomes (success or failure). For example, it applies in cases like the probability of a patient surviving or not. However, hospital admissions do not have a fixed number of trials and are not a sequence of independent successes or failures. Therefore, the binomial distribution is not suitable. (C) Uniform Poisson distribution: There is no standard probability distribution called a "uniform Poisson distribution." This could be a misinterpretation of either the Poisson distribution (which is correct) or the uniform distribution, which assumes equal probability for all values. Since hospital admissions can vary daily and are not evenly distributed, the uniform distribution would not be appropriate.

questions.text: The standard normal distribution:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Has variance = 1.0 because the standard normal distribution (Z-distribution) is a specific case of the normal distribution with a mean (?) of 0 and a standard deviation (?) of 1. The variance is the square of the standard deviation: Variance= ?2 =12=1 This standard form allows for easy comparison and conversion of normal distributions using Z-scores: Z=X – ?/ ? Incorrect Options: (A) Is skewed to the left: The standard normal distribution is a symmetric bell-shaped curve, meaning it is not skewed to the left or right. Skewness refers to the asymmetry of a distribution, but the standard normal distribution has a skewness of 0, making this option incorrect. (B) Has mean = 1.0: The mean (?) of the standard normal distribution is always 0, not 1. The standard normal distribution is centered at 0, meaning half the data lies to the left of 0 and half to the right. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. (C) Has standard deviation = 0.0: The standard deviation (?) of the standard normal distribution is 1.0, not 0.0. A standard deviation of 0 would mean there is no variability in the data, which is not the case for any normal distribution. Since the standard normal distribution has a standard deviation of 1, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A normal distribution curve depends on:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mean/ Median/ Mode +- 1 SD = 68%; +- 2SD = 95%; +- 3SD = 99% Incorrect Options: (A) Mean and sample size: The sample size (n) affects statistical inference (e.g., standard error) but does not define the normal distribution itself.
