who were immunizedagainst chickenpox subsequentlydevelop zoster than those who were not immunized

That the mean blood pressure of black and white male - hypertensivepatient taking ACE inhibitoris the same as the of black and white female hypertensivepatient taking ACE inhibitors and that of black and white males and females taking diureticsand placebos
That the mean cost of treating a patient with coronary artery disease with angioplasty in greater than the mean cost of providing medical treatment

questions.text: A chi square test wound be most appropriate for testing which one of the following hypotheses :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) "Who were immunized against chickenpox subsequently develop zoster more than those who were not immunized." Chi-square (?2) test is used to assess the association between categorical variables (nominal or ordinal data). In option (B), we have two categorical variables: Immunization status (Immunized vs. Not immunized) Development of zoster (Yes vs. No) A chi-square test of independence would be appropriate to determine if there is a significant association between immunization and the likelihood of developing zoster. Incorrect Options: (A) That the mean AIPGE score of Delhi students is greater than that of Mumbai students This hypothesis compares the means of two groups (Delhi vs. Mumbai students). A t-test or Mann-Whitney U test (for non-normal data) would be appropriate, not a chi-square test. (C) That the mean blood pressure of black and white male hypertensive patients taking ACE inhibitors is the same as that of black and white female hypertensive patients taking ACE inhibitors, and that of black and white males and females taking diuretics and placebos This involves comparing the means of multiple groups (black vs. white, male vs. female, and different treatments). An ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) test would be the correct choice for comparing multiple means, not a chi-square test. (D) That the mean cost of treating a patient with coronary artery disease with angioplasty is greater than the mean cost of providing medical treatment This compares the mean costs between two different treatments. A t-test would be used to compare the means of two groups, not a chi-square test.

questions.text: In a particular trial the association of lung cancer with smoking is found to be 40% in one sample and 60% in another . What is the best test to compare the result:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chi-square test. The chi-square (?2) test is used to compare the proportions or frequencies between two or more categorical groups. In this case, we have two categorical variables: Smoking status (Smoker vs. Non-smoker) Lung cancer status (Present vs. Absent) The problem presents proportions (40% vs. 60%) in two samples. The chi-square test will determine whether the observed difference in proportions is statistically significant or due to chance. Incorrect Options: (B) Fischer Test Fisher's exact test is used when the sample size is small (expected frequencies in any cell <5). If the sample size is large, the chi-square test is preferred. (C) Paired t-test A paired t-test is used to compare mean values before and after an intervention in the same group of individuals (e.g., pre-test vs. post-test). This question involves comparing proportions, not means, so a paired t-test is inappropriate. (D) ANOVA Test ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used to compare mean values across three or more groups. Since the data in this question involves categorical proportions (40% vs. 60%), ANOVA is not suitable.

questions.text: Height of group of 20 boysaged 10 years was 140 + 13 cm & 20 girl of same age was135 cm + 7 cm to test the statisticalsignificance of difference in height test applicable is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) T-test. A t-test is used to compare the means of two groups when the sample size is small (typically n Given Data: Boys: Mean = 140 cm, Standard Deviation = 13 cm, Sample size = 20 Girls: Mean = 135 cm, Standard Deviation = 7 cm, Sample size = 20 Since the sample sizes are small (n = 20 in each group) and we are comparing two independent means, the independent (unpaired) t-test is the appropriate statistical test. Explanation of Incorrect Options (A) Chi-square (?2) Test The chi-square test is used for categorical data (e.g., gender, presence/absence of a disease). Since we are comparing numerical (continuous) data (height in cm), chi-square is not appropriate. (B) Z-test A Z-test is used when the sample size is large (n > 30) and the population standard deviation is known. Since n = 20 in both groups and we are not given the population standard deviation, the t-test is preferred. (D) F-test An F-test is used to compare variances of two or more groups, not their means. Since the question asks for a test to compare the mean heights, the t-test is more appropriate

questions.text: The mean B.P of a group personwas determine and after an interventionaltrial the mean BP was estimated again . The best to be applied to determine the significance of intervention is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Paired t-test. A paired t-test is used when we compare the same group of individuals before and after an intervention. In this case, the blood pressure (BP) of the same group was measured before and after an intervention trial. Since each person serves as their own control, we analyze the difference in BP before and after rather than comparing two independent groups. The paired t-test helps determine if the change in BP after the intervention is statistically significant. Explanation of Incorrect Options (A) Chi-square (?2) Test Chi-square is used for categorical data (e.g., presence/absence of hypertension). Since BP is continuous numerical data, chi-square is not appropriate. (C) Correlation Coefficient Correlation measures the strength and direction of a relationship between two variables (e.g., BP vs. age). It does not test whether there is a significant difference before and after an intervention. (D) Independent t-test An independent t-test compares two separate groups (e.g., Group A vs. Group B). Here, we are comparing BP in the same individuals before and after an intervention, so the paired t-test is more appropriate.

questions.text: An investigator wants to study the association between maternal intake of iron supplements (yes or No)and incidence of low birth weight ( 2500) gms). He collects relevant data from 100 pregnant women as to the status of usage of iron supplementand the statusof low birth weightin their newborns. The appropriate statistical test of hypothesis advised in this situation is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) a. Number of groups = 2 b. Un Paired c. Output variable = qualitative (birth weight is over here taken as low or normal) d. Algorithm 1 = chi square

questions.text: While applying Chi square test to a contingencytable of 4 rows and 4 columns the degrees of freedom would be :
questions.solution: The correct answer is (C) 9. The degrees of freedom (df) in a Chi-square test for a contingency table is calculated using the formula: df=(r−1)×(c−1) Where: r = Number of rows c = Number of columns In this case: r = 4 (4 rows) c = 4 (4 columns) df=(4−1)×(4−1)=3×3=9 Explanation of Incorrect Options (A) 1 A degree of freedom of 1 occurs in a 2×2 contingency table, where df=(2−1)×(2−1)=1 Since our table is 4×4, this is incorrect. (B) 4 A 4×4 table does not result in df = 4. This might be confused with the number of rows or columns, but the formula requires subtracting 1 from both. (D) 8 If we had a 4×3 table, the degrees of freedom would be: (4−1)×(3−1)=3×2=6

questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of an antihypertensive drug. HE notes down the initial systolic blood pressure (mmHg ) of 50 patients and then administers the drugs on them. After a week’s treatment he measure the following is the most appropriate statistical test of significance to test the statistical significance of the changes in blood pressure :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Paired t-test. A paired t-test is used when two measurements are taken on the same subjects before and after an intervention. In this case, the cardiologist measures: Initial systolic blood pressure (Before Drug Administration) Systolic blood pressure after 1 week of treatment (After Drug Administration) Since each patient acts as their own control, the data points are paired (before and after values for the same individuals). The paired t-test compares the mean difference in blood pressure before and after treatment to determine if the change is statistically significant. Thus, the most appropriate statistical test is a paired t-test. Explanation of Incorrect Options (B) Unpaired or Independent t-test An unpaired t-test compares the means of two independent groups (e.g., treatment group vs. control group). Here, the same 50 patients are measured twice, making it a paired analysis rather than an independent one. (C) Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) ANOVA is used when comparing more than two groups or conditions. Since we are only comparing before and after measurements, ANOVA is unnecessary. (D) Chi-square test Chi-square is used for categorical data (e.g., Yes/No, Male/Female, Disease/No Disease). Here, the data (blood pressure) is continuous, so Chi-square is not applicable.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to assess the effect of a drug in lowering serum cholesterol level. 15 obese women and 10 non obese women formed the 2 limbs of the study. Which test would be useful to correlate the results obtained:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Student’s t-test. The Student’s t-test (also known as the independent t-test or unpaired t-test) is used to compare the means of two independent groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them. In this study: Two independent groups: Obese women (n = 15) Non-obese women (n = 10) Outcome variable: Serum cholesterol levels (continuous variable) Objective: To compare whether the drug had a different effect on serum cholesterol levels in the two independent groups (obese vs. non-obese). Since the study is comparing two independent groups, the unpaired Student’s t-test is the appropriate statistical test. Incorrect Options: (A) ANOVA test ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used when comparing more than two groups. Since this study only has two groups (obese vs. non-obese women), ANOVA is not needed. (C) Chi-square test Chi-square is used for categorical data (e.g., Disease/No Disease, Male/Female, Yes/No). Serum cholesterol levels are continuous variables, so Chi-square is not applicable. (D) Fischer test Fisher’s Exact Test is used for small sample sizes with categorical data. Since the outcome variable is continuous (serum cholesterol levels) and not categorical, Fisher’s test is not appropriate.

questions.text: Not required for Chi square test is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mean & SD of the groups. The Chi-square test is a non-parametric test that is used to analyze categorical data (e.g., Yes/No, Male/Female, Disease/No Disease). It does not require numerical summaries like Mean and Standard Deviation (SD), which are used for continuous variables. The Chi-square test is based on counts or frequencies in different categories, not numerical values like the mean or standard deviation. Since it analyzes proportions and associations in categorical data, measures like mean and SD are not relevant for its calculation. Incorrect Options: (B) Median & SD of the groups Similar to mean and SD, the median is also a measure of central tendency used for continuous data. Since the Chi-square test deals with categorical data, the median and SD are not required either. However, the question asks for what is not required, and mean and SD are more commonly linked to numerical data, making (A) the best answer. (C) Small sample The Chi-square test generally requires a large sample size for accurate results. However, when sample sizes are small (expected frequency < 5 in any cell of the contingency table), Fisher’s Exact Test is preferred. Chi-square can still be used with small samples in some cases, so this is not the best choice for what is "not required." (D) Contingency Table (2×2 Table) A 2×2 contingency table is commonly used in Chi-square tests to examine the association between two categorical variables. Larger contingency tables (e.g., 3×3, 4×4) can also be used, but the 2×2 table is a fundamental format for the test. Since Chi-square often requires contingency tables, this option is incorrect for what is "not required."

questions.text: Appropriate statistical method t compare two mean is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Student’s t-test. The Student’s t-test is used to compare the means of two groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them. It is applied when the data are continuous (numerical) and follow a normal distribution. The test calculates the t-statistic and compares it with a critical value from the t-distribution to determine significance. There are two types of t-tests: Independent (Unpaired) t-test – compares means of two separate groups. Paired t-test – compares means of the same group before and after an intervention. Since the question asks for a method to compare two means, the Student’s t-test is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Chi-square test The Chi-square test is used for categorical data (e.g., Yes/No, Male/Female) and measures associations between groups. Since we are comparing means, which involve numerical data, Chi-square is not appropriate. (C) Odds Ratio Odds Ratio (OR) is a measure used in case-control studies to compare the likelihood of an event occurring in one group versus another. It is not a statistical test for comparing means but rather for comparing proportions or risk factors. (D) Correlation Coefficient The correlation coefficient (r) measures the strength and direction of a relationship between two continuous variables (e.g., height and weight). It does not compare means but rather assesses association between two variables.

questions.text: Mean, median and mode are :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Measures of central tendency. Mean, median, and mode are statistical measures used to describe the center or average of a dataset. They provide a single representative value for a given dataset, summarizing the data distribution. Each measure has a specific use case: Mean (Average) – Sum of all values divided by the number of values. Median – The middle value when data is arranged in ascending order. Mode – The most frequently occurring value in the dataset. Since these three statistics summarize the central location of data, they are known as measures of central tendency. Incorrect Options: (A) Measure of Dispersion Measures of dispersion describe the spread or variability of data (e.g., range, variance, standard deviation). Mean, median, and mode describe the center of the data, not its dispersion. (B) Measure Association Between Two Variables This refers to tests like correlation coefficient (r) or regression analysis, which measure relationships between two variables. Mean, median, and mode describe a single dataset, not the relationship between two variables. (C) Test of Significance Tests of significance (e.g., t-test, chi-square test, ANOVA) are used to determine whether a result is statistically significant. Mean, median, and mode do not test significance; they summarize the data.

questions.text: In a given data , degree of freedom will be :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 6. How to Calculate Degrees of Freedom in a Contingency Table? The degrees of freedom (df) in a contingency table (used for the Chi-square test) is calculated using the formula: df=(Number of Rows?1)×(Number of Columns?1) Given: Number of Rows = 4 Number of Columns = 3 df=(4?1)×(3?1)=3×2=6 Thus, the correct answer is (B) 6. Incorrect Options: (A) 12 This would be the correct answer if the table had 5 rows and 4 columns, as (5-1) × (4-1) = 4 × 3 = 12. Since our table has 4 rows and 3 columns, this is incorrect. C) 9 A 3×4 table would have (3-1) × (4-1) = 2 × 3 = 6, not 9. A 4×5 table would give 9 degrees of freedom ((4-1) × (5-1) = 3 × 3 = 9). (D) 20 A degree of freedom of 20 would require a much larger table (like 5×6), where: (5?1)×(6?1)=4×5=20

choices.text: Tests the significance of difference between two proportions
Tells about presence or absenceof an association between two variables
Directly measures the strength of association
Can be used when more than two groups are to be compared

questions.text: Not true about Chi square test is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Directly measures the strength of association. The Chi-square test is used to determine whether there is a statistically significant association between two categorical variables. However, it does not directly measure the strength of the association. To measure the strength of association, we use other statistical measures such as: Relative Risk (RR) Odds Ratio (OR) Cramér’s V (for categorical data) Phi Coefficient (for 2×2 tables) Since the Chi-square test only tells us whether an association exists (significance), but not how strong it is, option (C) is incorrect. Incorrect Options: (A) Tests the significance of difference between two proportions ? The Chi-square test is commonly used to compare proportions across different groups. Example: Comparing the proportion of smokers vs. non-smokers in two different populations. (B) Tells about the presence or absence of an association between two variables ? Chi-square examines whether two categorical variables are independent or associated. It does not measure how strong the association is—just whether it exists. (D) Can be used when more than two groups are to be compared ? Unlike t-tests, which compare means of two groups, Chi-square can handle multiple groups. Example: Testing if blood type (A, B, AB, O) is associated with a particular disease.

questions.text: You have been asked to design a study for a disease whose prevalence in the community is 10%. The alpha error has to be kept at 5% with a relative precision of 20% and a power of 20%. What will be the accurate sample size for this study :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) At 95% confidence (obtained from alpha = 5%; Confidence = 100 – alpha); n = 4pq/2 Power has no role to play in sample size calculation for observational studies (evident from word prevalence) Absolute precision = Relative precision of Prevalence = 20 * 10 = 2% n = 4 * 10 *( 100- 10)/ (2 * 2) = 900 Incorrect Options: (B) 3600 This would be the sample size if the precision was much smaller (e.g., 1% instead of 2%). (C) 400 This is an underestimate and does not satisfy the formula. (D) 1800 This would be required if prevalence were lower or precision were tighter.

questions.text: In a study 2 groups of new born are checked for their weights based on whether mothers received food supplements or not. Appropriate statistical test is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) a. Number of groups = 2 b. Un Paired c. Output variable = qualitative (birth weight is over here taken as low or normal) d. Algorithm 1 = chi square

choices.text: Significance of difference between two proportions

questions.text: Chi square test is used to measure the degree of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The Chi-square (?2) test is used to determine whether there is a significant association between two categorical variables. One of its primary applications is testing the difference between two proportions to see if the observed frequencies significantly differ from expected frequencies. It is commonly used in contingency tables (e.g., 2×2 tables) where data is classified into different categories (e.g., vaccinated vs. non-vaccinated, diseased vs. non-diseased). It does not measure causation, correlation, or agreement but only checks for an association between variables. Since proportions are based on categorical data (e.g., "Yes/No", "Present/Absent"), the Chi-square test is appropriate for comparing them. Significance of difference between two proportions Incorrect Options: (B) Causation between two variables The Chi-square test does not establish causation; it only detects association. Causation requires further study designs like cohort studies, randomized controlled trials (RCTs), or regression analysis. (C) Correlation between two variables Correlation measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two continuous variables (e.g., height and weight). The Pearson correlation coefficient (r) or Spearman rank correlation is used for this, not the Chi-square test. (D) Agreement between two observations Agreement analysis (e.g., kappa statistic) is used for checking inter-rater reliability (e.g., whether two doctors give the same diagnosis). The Chi-square test is not used for agreement measurements.

questions.text: All of the these are continuous variable except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Blood Groups A, B, AB, O. A continuous variable is one that can take an infinite number of values within a given range, meaning it can be measured with increasing levels of precision (e.g., 1.1 cm, 1.12 cm, 1.123 cm, etc.). However, blood groups (A, B, AB, O) are categorical variables because: They do not have a numerical value and cannot be measured on a continuous scale. They belong to distinct categories with no meaningful order or gradation. Even though they provide useful classification, they are not continuous variables. Incorrect Options: (A) Height in CMS (Continuous Variable) Height is measured on a continuous scale (e.g., 150.2 cm, 150.25 cm, etc.). It can take any fractional value within a reasonable range. (B) Weight in KGS (Continuous Variable) Weight is also a continuous variable as it can take an infinite number of values (e.g., 60.1 kg, 60.12 kg, etc.). It is measurable and does not fall into fixed categories. (D) Age in years and months (Continuous Variable) Age is a continuous variable because it can be measured precisely (e.g., 25.4 years, 25.45 years, etc.). Although we often express it in whole numbers, it has decimal values in practice

questions.text: 1 degree of freedom between two qualitative variables done by chi square is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The Chi-square test is a statistical method used to determine the association between two categorical (qualitative) variables. • The degree of freedom (df) for a 2×2 contingency table is calculated as: df=(Rows−1)×(Columns−1) For a 2×2 table, df=(2−1)×(2−1)=1 The critical value of the chi-square distribution for 1 degree of freedom at a 5% significance level (α = 0.05) is 3.84. If the calculated chi-square value exceeds 3.84, we reject the null hypothesis and conclude that there is a significant association between the two variables. Incorrect Options: (A) 0.45 A Chi-square value of 0.45 is much lower than the critical value (3.84). This would not be significant at α = 0.05, meaning we would fail to reject the null hypothesis and conclude that there is no strong association between the variables. (B) 2.41 A Chi-square value of 2.41 is also less than 3.84, meaning it is not statistically significant at the 5% level. This means the two qualitative variables might not have a strong association. (D) 4.34 While 4.34 is greater than 3.84, it is not the standard critical value for 1 degree of freedom at α = 0.05. It may correspond to a different confidence level (e.g., α = 0.025), but it is not the correct answer in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for selecting patient with respect to potential factors that will affect the results :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stratified random sampling. Correct Explanation (Stratified Random Sampling for Selecting Patients Based on Factors) Stratified random sampling is a method where a population is divided into meaningful subgroups (strata) based on specific factors that may affect the study results. These factors can include age, gender, disease severity, or other relevant characteristics. Then, random samples are taken from each subgroup to ensure representation of all key groups in the study. This method reduces variability and increases the accuracy of comparisons between groups, making it ideal for selecting patients while considering potential confounding factors. Incorrect Options: (A) Systematic random sampling (Not based on factors, uses fixed intervals) Systematic sampling selects individuals at regular intervals (e.g., every 5th or 10th patient) from a list. It does not account for specific factors that may influence results, so it is not suitable when patient characteristics need to be controlled. (B) Simple random sampling (Purely random, does not consider factors) Simple random sampling gives each individual an equal chance of being selected without grouping by relevant factors. This may not ensure balanced representation of different patient groups that could influence study outcomes. (D) Cluster sampling (Used for large groups, not for controlling variables) Cluster sampling divides the population into clusters (e.g., hospitals, schools, or cities) and randomly selects entire clusters rather than individuals. This method is useful for large-scale studies but does not control for specific patient factors.

choices.text: Less no . of samples are associated with less error
Categories of data used in test need not be mutually exclusive and discrete

questions.text: About chi square test true is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) < 0.001 is statistically significant. The Chi-square test is used to test the association between two categorical variables. The p-value obtained from the test determines whether the observed association is statistically significant. If p < 0.05, the association is statistically significant (i.e., unlikely due to chance). If p < 0.001, the association is highly statistically significant, meaning there is strong evidence that the relationship is not due to random variation. Incorrect Options: (B) Less number of samples are associated with less error (Incorrect, smaller samples have more error) A smaller sample size increases the chance of error and variability in the results. The Chi-square test requires a sufficiently large sample to provide accurate results. Small samples may lead to inaccurate p-values and a higher risk of Type II error (false negatives). (C) Categories of data used in test need not be mutually exclusive and discrete (Incorrect, data must be categorical and mutually exclusive) The Chi-square test requires categorical data where each observation belongs to only one category (e.g., male/female, diseased/healthy). If the categories are not mutually exclusive, the test results may be misleading. (D) Tests correlation and regression (Incorrect, Chi-square test does not measure correlation or regression) The Chi-square test measures association, not correlation or regression. Correlation (Pearson’s r) and regression (linear/logistic regression) deal with numerical (continuous) variables, while Chi-square is used for categorical variables.

questions.text: A study who planned to find out the effect of iron supplementation during pregnancy on the birth weight of new born children. Two group one with iron supplementation and the other without iron supplementation and the other without iron supplementation during pregnancy were compared. Birth weight of new borne were recorded as means + SD. Which Statistical test is appropriate for comparison of birth weights between the two groups:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Unpaired t-test. Correct Explanation (Why Unpaired t-test is Used) The study compares the mean birth weight between two independent groups: Mothers who received iron supplementation Mothers who did not receive iron supplementation Since the birth weights are recorded as means ± standard deviation (SD), it indicates continuous data (numerical values). The Unpaired t-test (Independent t-test) is used to compare the means of two independent groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them. It assumes normal distribution of the birth weight data in both groups and equal or unequal variance based on variance tests (e.g., Levene’s test). Incorrect Options: (B) Paired t-test (Incorrect, used for dependent samples, not independent groups) A paired t-test is used when the same subjects are measured twice (before and after an intervention). In this study, two separate groups are compared, not repeated measurements on the same individuals. A paired t-test would be appropriate if the same women had birth weight measured in two different pregnancies (with and without iron supplementation). (C) McNemar’s Test (Incorrect, used for paired categorical data, not continuous data) McNemar’s test is used for paired categorical data (e.g., presence or absence of disease before and after treatment). Since birth weight is a continuous variable, McNemar’s test is not appropriate. (D) Chi-square Test (Incorrect, used for categorical data, not continuous variables) Chi-square test is used to test associations between categorical (nominal) variables (e.g., low birth weight vs. normal birth weight). Since the study deals with continuous data (birth weight in kg or grams), Chi-square is not suitable.

choices.text: To compare means in 3 or more groups
To compare mean in 1 group before and after intervention

questions.text: ANOVA is used :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) To compare means in 3 or more groups. ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is a statistical test used to compare the means of three or more independent groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them. It extends the t-test, which is used for comparing only two groups. ANOVA helps in analyzing multiple group comparisons while controlling for Type I errors (false positives) that may arise from multiple t-tests. Common examples: Comparing blood pressure levels among three different age groups. Assessing the effectiveness of three different medications on blood sugar levels. Incorrect Options: (A) To compare means in 2 groups (Incorrect, use a t-test instead) If there are only two groups, a t-test (independent or paired t-test) is more appropriate. ANOVA is specifically designed for comparing 3 or more groups. (C) To compare mean in 1 group before and after intervention (Incorrect, use a paired t-test instead) When comparing the same group before and after an intervention, a paired t-test (dependent t-test) is used. ANOVA is not necessary when there are only two time points (before and after) for a single group. (D) To find correlation (Incorrect, use correlation tests instead) ANOVA does not measure correlation between two variables. Correlation is measured using Pearson’s correlation coefficient (r) or Spearman’s rank correlation depending on the data type.

questions.text: Apgar scores of 30 children are recorded in a hospital and most of the reading are found to be 7 or above . what can you out about this data distribution :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Negatively skewed. Apgar scores measure the physical condition of newborns immediately after birth, with higher scores (7 or above) indicating better health. Since most of the values are 7 or above, the majority of the data points are concentrated on the right (higher) end of the distribution. Negative skewness means that the tail of the distribution is longer on the left (lower values). In this case, fewer babies have very low Apgar scores, leading to a longer tail on the left side and a negative skew. Incorrect Options: (A) Positively skewed A positively skewed distribution has more low values with a longer right tail. If the majority of Apgar scores were low (e.g., 0-3) with only a few high scores, the data would be positively skewed. Since most scores are 7 or above, this is not the case. (C) Normal distribution A normal distribution is bell-shaped and symmetric around the mean. If the Apgar scores were evenly spread around a central value (e.g., 5-6), then it would be normally distributed. However, since most scores are high (7 or above) and not evenly spread, the data is not normal. (D) Symmetrically skewed data Skewed distributions are never symmetric by definition. Symmetric data means the left and right sides mirror each other, which is not the case here because the tail is only on the left side.

questions.text: In a centre the number of nodes dissected during 20 modified radical mastectomy were plottedin the form of a cure and there arethree marking on the below curve. Based on the distribution type of curve which of the following is correct
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mean > Median > Mode. Understanding the Distribution Type The question suggests that the number of dissected nodes is plotted in a curve and that three markings (mean, median, and mode) are present below the curve. The positioning of these values helps determine the type of skewness: Positively skewed distribution (Right-skewed): Mean > Median > Mode This occurs when there are a few very high values pulling the mean to the right. The tail extends to the right (higher values). Negatively skewed distribution (Left-skewed): Mode > Median > Mean This occurs when a few very low values pull the mean to the left. The tail extends to the left (lower values). In modified radical mastectomy, the number of dissected lymph nodes typically varies, but some patients may have very high node counts, leading to a right-skewed (positively skewed) distribution. In a right-skewed distribution: The mode (most frequent value) is at the peak of the curve. The median (middle value) is slightly to the right of the mode. The mean (which is affected by extreme values) is the farthest to the right. Since the question suggests this type of distribution, the relationship follows: Mean > Median > Mode Incorrect Options: (B) Mode > Mean > Median This would be true in a negatively skewed (left-skewed) distribution, where extreme low values pull the mean lower than the mode and median. Since the question implies right-skewed data, this is incorrect. (C) Median > Mode > Mean This pattern does not match any standard skewness. If the median is greater than the mode, it suggests left-skewed data, but the mean would be even lower, making Mode > Median > Mean the correct order for left skewness. (D) Mode > Median > Mean This is the correct relationship for left-skewed (negatively skewed) distributions, where a few extreme low values pull the mean lower than the median and mode. Since mastectomy node counts tend to have a few very high values, making the distribution right-skewed, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Test is used to compare Kaplan Meier survival curve :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cox proportional hazards test. Kaplan-Meier survival curves are used in survival analysis to estimate the probability of survival over time. When comparing survival curves between two or more groups, we need a statistical test to determine if the difference is significant. The Cox proportional hazards model is the most appropriate test for comparing Kaplan-Meier survival curves, as it: Accounts for covariates that may influence survival. Analyzes hazard ratios (risk over time). Handles censored data, which is common in survival analysis. Thus, Cox proportional hazards test is the best choice for comparing Kaplan-Meier survival curves. Incorrect Options: (A) ANOVA ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used for comparing means across three or more groups. It is not designed for survival data, which involves time-to-event analysis and censored data. Since Kaplan-Meier survival curves deal with survival probability over time, ANOVA is not suitable. (B) Bland-Altman Analysis Bland-Altman analysis is used to assess agreement between two measurement techniques (e.g., comparing two blood pressure devices). It does not compare survival curves. It focuses on measurement differences, not survival probabilities. (C) Chi-Square Test Chi-square test is used for comparing categorical data (e.g., treatment vs. no treatment outcomes). It does not handle time-to-event data. It cannot properly account for censored observations (when survival data is incomplete due to study ending before death/event).

choices.text: Pre frontal blood flow under cognitiveload is a good predictor of the severity of psychotic symptoms in schizophrenic patients
Prefrontal blood flow under cognitive load accounts for a large proportion of the variance in psychotic symptoms in schizophrenic patients
Psychosis or schizophrenia is in some way a cause or partial cause of low prefrontal blood flow under cognitive load
The lecturer has reportedthe correlation coefficient incorrectly :

questions.text: A lecturer states that the correlation coefficient between prefrontal blood flow under cognitive load and the severity of psychotic symptoms in schizophrenic patientsis - 1.24 you can therefore conclude that :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The lecturer has reported the correlation coefficient incorrectly. The correlation coefficient (r) ranges from -1 to +1. -1 indicates a perfect negative correlation (strong inverse relationship). +1 indicates a perfect positive correlation (strong direct relationship). 0 indicates no correlation (no relationship between variables). In this case, the lecturer reported r = -1.24, which is not possible since it is outside the valid range (-1 to +1). Therefore, the lecturer must have made an error in reporting the correlation coefficient. Thus, the correct conclusion is that the lecturer has made a mistake in reporting the correlation coefficient. Incorrect Options: (A) Prefrontal blood flow under cognitive load is a good predictor of the severity of psychotic symptoms A correlation coefficient greater than 1 or less than -1 is invalid, meaning we cannot make any conclusions about the relationship. Even if the correlation were within a valid range, correlation does not imply causation or predictive power. (B) Prefrontal blood flow under cognitive load accounts for a large proportion of the variance in psychotic symptoms The proportion of variance explained by a correlation is given by r² (coefficient of determination). Since r = -1.24 is invalid, we cannot compute r², and thus this statement is meaningless. (C) Psychosis or schizophrenia is in some way a cause or partial cause of low prefrontal blood flow under cognitive load Correlation does not imply causation—just because two variables are correlated does not mean one causes the other. Even if a valid negative correlation existed (e.g., r = -0.8), it would still not prove that schizophrenia causes low prefrontal blood flow.

choices.text: Since there is a high correlationthe magnitudes of boththe measurements are likely to be close to each other
A patient with a high level of systolic BP is also likelyto have a high level of serum cholesterol
A patient with a low level of systolic BP is also likely to have a low level of serum cholesterol
About 80% of the variation in systolic blood pressure among his patients can be explained by theirserum values and vice a versa :

questions.text: A cardiologist found a highly significant correlation coefficient ( r = 0.90, p = 0.01) between the systolic blood patient attending his clinic which of the following statement is a wrong interpretation of the correlation coefficient observed :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Since there is a high correlation, the magnitudes of both the measurements are likely to be close to each other. Correlation (r) measures the strength and direction of a relationship between two variables, but it does not imply that their magnitudes are similar. In this case, r = 0.90 indicates a strong positive correlation between systolic blood pressure and serum cholesterol levels, meaning that as one increases, the other also tends to increase. However, this does not mean that the numerical values of systolic BP and serum cholesterol are close to each other. For example, SBP = 180 mmHg and cholesterol = 250 mg/dL might still have a strong correlation, but their magnitudes are different. Correlation only tells us about the relationship, not absolute values. Other options: (B) A patient with a high level of systolic BP is also likely to have a high level of serum cholesterol (Correct) Since r = 0.90 is strong and positive, an increase in one variable (systolic BP) is strongly associated with an increase in the other variable (serum cholesterol). This statement correctly describes the meaning of a strong positive correlation. (C) A patient with a low level of systolic BP is also likely to have a low level of serum cholesterol (Correct) Again, a strong positive correlation means both variables tend to move in the same direction. If systolic BP is low, serum cholesterol is also likely to be low. (D) About 80% of the variation in systolic blood pressure among his patients can be explained by their serum cholesterol values and vice versa ? (Correct) The coefficient of determination (r²) tells us how much of the variability in one variable can be explained by the other. Since r = 0.90, we compute: r² = (0.90)² = 0.81 \text{ (or 81%)} This means 81% of the variability in systolic BP can be explained by serum cholesterol levels, making this a valid interpretation.

choices.text: It indicates degree of associationbetween two characteristics
Correlation coefficient of 1meansthat the two variables exhibitlinearrelationship
Correlationof 1 mean that the twovariables exhibited linearrelationship

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about correlation :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It indicates degree of associationbetween two characteristics Correlation does measure association, but it does not indicate the degree of association in terms of causation. Correlation only quantifies how strongly two variables move together but does not imply that one causes the other. The correct interpretation should be: Correlation measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables, not necessarily the "degree of association" in a causal sense. Therefore, while correlation does indicate a relationship, the phrase "degree of association" might be misleading, making (A) the correct choice for what is NOT true. Other options (B) Correlation coefficient of 1 means that the two variables exhibit a linear relationship (Correct) A correlation of +1 or -1 indicates a perfect linear relationship. r = +1 means that as one variable increases, the other also increases proportionally. r = -1 means that as one variable increases, the other decreases in a perfectly linear fashion. (C) Correlation of 1 means that the two variables exhibited a linear relationship (Correct) This is simply another way of stating (B). A correlation of 1 or -1 means that all data points perfectly fit on a straight line. (D) Causation implies correlation (Correct) If A causes B, then A and B must be correlated because changes in A will necessarily be associated with changes in B. However, the reverse is not true—correlation does not imply causation. For example, ice cream sales and drowning rates are correlated, but eating ice cream does not cause drowning; both increase due to hot weather.

questions.text: If the correlation of height with age is given by the equation y=a + bc, what would be the nature of the graph :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Straight line. • The given equation is in the form: y=a+bc • This is a linear equation (similar to the form y = mx + c, where m is the slope and c is the intercept). • The equation suggests a direct proportional relationship between y (height) and x (age), meaning as age increases, height also increases (or decreases) in a linear fashion. • Graphically, a linear equation always results in a straight line when plotted. Thus, the nature of the graph is a straight line. Why are the Other Options Incorrect? (B) Parabola A parabolic graph appears when an equation has a squared term (e.g., y = ax2 + bx + c). • The given equation does not contain an x2 term, so the graph cannot be a parabola. (C) Hyperbola • A hyperbolic relationship is represented by an equation of the form y = a/x or y = ax-1. • The given equation does not contain any reciprocal (1/x) terms, so the graph cannot be a hyperbola. (D) Sigmoid Curve • A sigmoid (S-shaped) curve is typically represented by an equation like the logistic function: y=1/1 + e-x • This type of curve is commonly seen in biological growth and probability models, but the given equation does not fit this pattern.

questions.text: What can be true regarding the coefficient of correlation between IMR and economic status :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) r = -0.8 The correlation coefficient (r) measures the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) refers to the number of infant deaths per 1,000 live births. Economic status is typically measured using indicators like income, GDP per capita, or socioeconomic index. In general, as economic status improves, IMR decreases (better healthcare, nutrition, and living conditions). This indicates a negative correlation between the two variables. A strong negative correlation (r = -0.8) suggests that higher economic status is strongly associated with lower IMR. The closer r is to -1, the stronger the negative correlation. Thus, r = -0.8 is the best choice, representing a strong inverse relationship between IMR and economic status. Incorrect Options: (A) r = +1 A correlation of +1 means a perfect positive correlation, where both variables increase together. This would imply that as economic status improves, IMR increases, which is unrealistic. IMR and economic status have an inverse relationship, not a positive one. (B) r = -1 r = -1 indicates a perfect negative correlation, meaning that every increase in economic status leads to an exactly proportional decrease in IMR. While there is a strong negative correlation, it is not necessarily perfect. Real-world data usually do not show perfect correlations due to various influencing factors. (C) r = +0.22 A correlation of +0.22 suggests a weak positive relationship, implying that IMR slightly increases with economic status, which contradicts real-world observations. A positive correlation would mean that higher economic status leads to higher IMR, which does not make sense.

choices.text: Strong statistically significant (+) associationbetween work satisfactionand life expectancy
70% peoples who enjoy work shall live longer
70% association between work satisfaction & life expectancy

questions.text: Study finds a correlation coefficient of + 0.7 between self reported work satisfaction & expectancy of life in a random sample of 5000 corporate workers. (p=0.01)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Strong statistically significant (+) association between work satisfaction and life expectancy A correlation coefficient (r) of +0.7 indicates a strong positive correlation between self-reported work satisfaction and life expectancy. A p-value of 0.01 suggests that this correlation is statistically significant, meaning there is a very low probability (1%) that the observed relationship occurred by chance. However, correlation does not imply causation—we cannot conclude that work satisfaction causes longer life expectancy. The correct interpretation is that higher work satisfaction is strongly associated with higher life expectancy. Thus, (B) is the best answer as it correctly describes the statistical significance and positive association. Incorrect Options: (A) Work satisfaction improves life expectancy Correlation does not establish causation. While there is a positive association, this does not mean that higher work satisfaction directly leads to a longer life. Other factors, such as health, income, stress levels, and lifestyle choices, could influence life expectancy. (C) 70% of people who enjoy work shall live longer A correlation coefficient of 0.7 does NOT mean that 70% of people with work satisfaction will live longer. The correlation coefficient only measures the strength of association, not the percentage of affected individuals. (D) 70% association between work satisfaction & life expectancy The value 0.7 does not represent a percentage of association. Instead, it describes the strength of the linear relationship between the two variables. A correlation of +0.7 means a strong positive relationship, not a 70?fect.

choices.text: Strong direct relationship between two variables
Strong inverse relationship between two variable
One variable is the cause of the other variable

questions.text: A coefficient of correlation value of “ r = +0.8” indicates :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Strong direct relationship between two variables The correlation coefficient (r) = +0.8 indicates a strong positive correlation between the two variables. A positive correlation means that as one variable increases, the other also tends to increase. The closer r is to +1, the stronger the direct relationship between the variables. Since r = +0.8 is close to +1, it suggests a strong positive association. (A) is the correct answer because it accurately describes the nature of a correlation coefficient of +0.8. Incorrect Options: (B) Strong inverse relationship between two variables A negative correlation (r < 0) represents an inverse relationship, where one variable increases as the other decreases. Since r = +0.8 (positive value), it means a direct relationship, not an inverse one. (C) Insignificant association between two variables A correlation of +0.8 is considered strong, indicating a significant relationship. A weak or insignificant correlation is typically close to 0 (e.g., r = 0.1 or r = -0.05). (D) One variable is the cause of the other variable Correlation does not imply causation—just because two variables are strongly related does not mean that one causes the other. The relationship could be influenced by other factors (confounders) or coincidence.

questions.text: Mosquitoes decrease as height increases in :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Negative correlation Negative correlation means that as one variable increases, the other decreases. In this case, as height increases, the number of mosquitoes decreases. Higher altitudes generally have lower temperatures, less humidity, and lower oxygen levels, which are less favorable for mosquito survival. Since the two variables move in opposite directions, this represents a negative correlation. Incorrect Options: (A) Positive correlation A positive correlation means that as one variable increases, the other also increases. If mosquitoes increased with height, then it would be a positive correlation. However, since mosquitoes decrease with increasing height, the correlation is negative, not positive. (C) Bidirectional correlation A bidirectional correlation implies that the relationship between the two variables goes both ways (e.g., they affect each other mutually). In this case, mosquitoes do not influence height, and height does not change due to mosquitoes. The relationship is one-directional (negative correlation), not bidirectional. (D) Zero correlation Zero correlation means there is no relationship between the two variables. However, there is a clear relationship—as height increases, mosquito numbers decrease. Therefore, the correlation is not zero but negative.

questions.text: Strong correlation is signified by a correlation coefficient of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A correlation coefficient (denoted as r) measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables. The correct answer is (B) 1, as a correlation coefficient of 1 signifies a perfect positive correlation. This means that as one variable increases, the other variable increases in a perfectly linear manner. In other words, knowing the value of one variable allows for an exact prediction of the other variable. This is the strongest possible correlation in a positive direction. Incorrect Options: (A) Zero: A correlation coefficient of zero indicates no correlation between the two variables. This means that changes in one variable do not predict changes in the other. The relationship, if any, is random or non-linear. (C) Less than 1: While values less than 1 (but greater than 0) do indicate a positive correlation, they do not represent a strong or perfect correlation. The strength of correlation increases as the value of r approaches 1, but any value below 1 means some degree of variability remains unexplained. (D) More than 1: The correlation coefficient is always constrained between -1 and 1. A value greater than 1 is mathematically impossible and does not exist in statistics.

questions.text: 4 populations had correlation coefficients of 0.6, each for weight & height, when plotted together. What would be the net coefficient if correlation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) When multiple populations have the same correlation coefficient (0.6 in this case) for the same variables (weight and height), the overall correlation coefficient remains the same. This is because correlation is a standardized measure that does not depend on the sample size or the number of groups, as long as the relationships within each group are consistent. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Same. Incorrect Options: (B) Smaller: The correlation coefficient would decrease only if the populations had different correlation values, especially if some were weaker or closer to zero. Since all populations have a correlation of 0.6, there is no reason for the overall coefficient to be smaller. (C) Greater: The correlation coefficient does not increase simply by combining multiple groups if their individual correlation values remain the same. If the populations had a stronger correlation individually (e.g., 0.8 or 0.9), then the overall coefficient could be high, but in this case, it remains at 0.6. (D) Can’t be predicted: Since all populations have the same correlation coefficient, the overall correlation is predictable and remains unchanged at 0.6. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Type I sampling error is classified as :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A Type I error occurs when a true null hypothesis is incorrectly rejected. This is also known as a false positive or alpha (?) error. In statistical hypothesis testing, the significance level (?) represents the probability of making a Type I error. It is the threshold set by researchers (commonly 0.05 or 5%) to determine whether to reject the null hypothesis. Since a Type I error corresponds to an alpha error, the correct answer is (A) Alpha error. Incorrect Options: (B) Beta error: A Type II error, also called beta (?) error, occurs when a false null hypothesis is incorrectly accepted (false negative). This is different from a Type I error, making this option incorrect. (C) Gamma error: There is no widely recognized statistical concept called Gamma error in hypothesis testing. This term is not used in relation to Type I or Type II errors, making this option incorrect. (D) Delta error: Delta (?) is commonly used to represent effect size in statistics, but it is not associated with a specific type of sampling error. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: The “ P” value of a randomized controlled trial comparing operation A ( new procedure) & operation B (Gold standard ) is 0.04. From this, we conclude that :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A p-value of 0.04 indicates that there is a 4% probability of obtaining the observed difference (or a more extreme one) between Operation A and Operation B, assuming that the null hypothesis is true. In other words, if there were no real difference between the two procedures, we would expect to see this result purely by chance only 4% of the time. Since a Type I error (false positive) refers to incorrectly rejecting the null hypothesis (i.e., concluding that Operation A is better than Operation B when it actually is not), the correct answer is (D): The probability of a false positive conclusion is 4%. Incorrect Options: (A) Type II error is small & we can accept the finding of the study: The p-value only informs us about the probability of a Type I error, not a Type II error (which is the failure to detect a real difference). A small p-value does not necessarily mean that the Type II error is small. Therefore, this statement is incorrect. (B) The probability of a false negative conclusion is 4%: A false negative (Type II error) occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis. The p-value does not measure Type II error or its probability, so this statement is incorrect. (C) The power of the study to detect a difference between Operation A & B is 96%: The power of a study is calculated as 1 - ? (Type II error probability), but the p-value does not provide direct information about the power of the study. The 96% value is misleading because power depends on factors like sample size and effect size, not just the p-value. Thus, this statement is incorrect.

questions.text: Power of study can be increased by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The power of a study is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis (i.e., detecting a true effect when one exists). Mathematically, power is defined as 1 - ?, where ? is the probability of a Type II error (false negative). Since power and ? error are inversely related, decreasing ? error increases the power of the study. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) Decreasing beta error. Incorrect Options: (A) Increasing alpha error: Increasing ? (Type I error) means lowering the threshold for statistical significance, which might make the study more likely to detect an effect. However, this also increases the likelihood of false positives. While a slight increase in ? can marginally increase power, it is not the primary method for improving power. The more effective approach is reducing ? by increasing the sample size or effect size. Thus, this is not the best answer. (C) Decreasing alpha error: Decreasing ? (Type I error) makes the test more conservative, reducing the chances of falsely rejecting the null hypothesis. However, this also makes it harder to detect a true effect, thereby reducing power instead of increasing it. Thus, this option is incorrect. (D) Increasing beta error: Since power = 1 - ?, increasing ? (Type II error) will decrease power, making the study less likely to detect a true difference. This is the opposite of what is needed to increase power, making this option incorrect

questions.text: In assisting the association between maternal nutritional status and birth weight of the newborns, two investigators A and B studied separately and found significant results with p values 0.02 and 0.04 respectively . From this information, what can you infer about the magnitudes of association found by the two investigations :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A p-value indicates the statistical significance of an observed association but does not directly provide information about the magnitude (strength) of the association. The magnitude of association is typically measured using effect size metrics such as odds ratio (OR), relative risk (RR), or regression coefficients. Since the problem only provides p-values (0.02 and 0.04) without any effect size estimates, we cannot determine whether Investigator A found a stronger or weaker association compared to Investigator B. Therefore, the correct answer is (D) Nothing can be concluded as the information given is inadequate. Incorrect Options: (A) The magnitude of association found by investigator A is more than that found by B: A lower p-value (e.g., 0.02 vs. 0.04) only indicates a stronger statistical evidence against the null hypothesis, but it does not mean the effect size (magnitude of association) is larger. The strength of association depends on effect size, not just significance level. Thus, this option is incorrect. (B) The magnitude of association found by investigator B is more than that found by A: Similarly, a higher p-value (0.04 vs. 0.02) does not indicate a smaller or weaker effect size. Since p-values depend on both effect size and sample size, it is incorrect to conclude that Investigator B found a stronger association than A. (C) The estimates of association obtained by A and B will be equal since both are significant: Just because both studies found statistically significant results does not mean the magnitude of their associations is equal. The effect size could still vary significantly between studies despite similar p-values. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

questions.text: A randomized trial comparing efficacy of two regimens showed that difference is statically signification with p < 0.001 but in reality the two drugs do not differs in their efficacy. This is an example of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A Type I error (? error) occurs when a true null hypothesis is incorrectly rejected, meaning we conclude there is a difference between two treatments when, in reality, there is none. In this case, the study found a statistically significant difference (p Incorrect Options: (B) Type II error (? error): A Type II error (? error) occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis—meaning we conclude that there is no difference between the two treatments when, in reality, there is a difference. However, in this case, the study incorrectly found a difference when none existed, so this is not a Type II error. (C) 1 - ?: The term 1 - ? represents the specificity of a statistical test, which is the probability of correctly not rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true. This is not related to the given scenario, making this option incorrect. (D) 1 - ?: The term 1 - ? represents the power of the study, which is the probability of correctly detecting a real difference when one exists. Since this scenario involves a false positive result, it is unrelated to power, making this option incorrect.

choices.text: The probabilityof finding a significant difference is 1 %

questions.text: After applying a statistical test an investigator gets the ‘ P value ‘ as 0.01 . It means that :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A p-value of 0.01 means that there is a 1% probability of obtaining the observed results (or more extreme ones) if the null hypothesis were true. In other words, the chance of a false positive (Type I error) is 1%, and if we repeat the experiment many times under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true, we would expect to find a significant result 1% of the time and a non-significant result 99% of the time. Therefore, the correct answer is (C): "The difference is not significant 1% times and significant 99%." Incorrect Options: (A) The probability of finding a significant difference is 1%: This statement is incorrect because the p-value does not indicate the probability of finding a significant difference; rather, it represents the probability of observing the data (or more extreme results) assuming the null hypothesis is true. (B) The probability of declaring a significant difference is 1%: A p-value of 0.01 does not indicate the probability of declaring significance. Instead, it represents the likelihood of obtaining the observed results if the null hypothesis is actually true. Statistical significance is based on comparison with the pre-set alpha level (e.g., 0.05), and since 0.01 is below this threshold, the result is significant. However, the statement as written is misleading. (D) The power of the test used is 99%: Power (1 - ?) is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis. The p-value does not measure power; power depends on factors like sample size, effect size, and variance, and it must be calculated separately. Therefore, this statement is incorrect

choices.text: Is the probability of committing Type - I error
Is the chance that the presence of difference is concluded when actuallythere is none
When p- value is less than alpha , the result is statistically significant

questions.text: All are true about p - value except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The p-value represents the probability of obtaining the observed results (or more extreme results) if the null hypothesis is true. It is primarily associated with Type I error (α error) and is used to determine statistical significance. "Is equal to 1 - β," because the p-value is NOT related to statistical power (1 - β). The power of a study is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis, whereas the p-value measures the strength of evidence against a true null hypothesis. Incorrect Options: (A) Is the probability of committing Type I error: This is partially correct because the p-value represents the probability of observing the data (or more extreme data) given that the null hypothesis is true. If the null hypothesis is rejected based on the p-value, there is a risk of making a Type I error (false positive). While the p-value itself is not exactly the Type I error rate, it is used to control the risk of such an error. (C) Is the chance that the presence of difference is concluded when actually there is none: This statement is another way of describing a Type I error. When the null hypothesis is true, but the p-value is small enough to reject it, we falsely conclude that a difference exists. Since the p-value reflects the probability of this happening under the null hypothesis, this statement is correct. (D) When p-value is less than alpha, the result is statistically significant: This is correct because in hypothesis testing, if the p-value is less than the chosen alpha level (e.g., 0.05), we reject the null hypothesis and declare the result statistically significant. This is a standard rule in statistical decision-making.

questions.text: All are true except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) "When the null hypothesis is true but is rejected, it is Type-II error." This statement is incorrect because rejecting a true null hypothesis is a Type I error (? error), not a Type II error. A Type II error (? error) occurs when the null hypothesis is false but is incorrectly not rejected (false negative). Incorrect Options: (A) Alpha is the maximum tolerable probability of Type I error: Correct. Alpha (?) is the predefined significance level (usually 0.05 or 5%) that represents the maximum acceptable probability of making a Type I error—rejecting a true null hypothesis. (B) Beta is the probability of Type II errors: Correct. Beta (?) is the probability of making a Type II error, which happens when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis (false negative). The power of a test is 1 - ?. (D) P-value can be more or less than ?: Correct. The p-value is the calculated probability of observing the data assuming the null hypothesis is true. It can be: Less than ? ? The result is statistically significant (reject null hypothesis). Greater than ? ? The result is not statistically significant (fail to reject null hypothesis).

choices.text: Not rejecting a null hypothesis when true
Rejecting a null hypothesis when true
Not rejecting a null hypothesis when false
Rejecting a null hypothesis when false

questions.text: P- value is the probability of :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rejecting a null hypothesis when true. A p-value represents the probability of obtaining the observed data (or more extreme results) assuming the null hypothesis is true. If the p-value is very small (e.g., < 0.05), we reject the null hypothesis. However, if the null hypothesis is actually true, rejecting it would be a Type I error (false positive). Therefore, the p-value is the probability of rejecting a true null hypothesis, making option (B) correct. Incorrect Options: (A) Not rejecting a null hypothesis when true: This describes the correct acceptance of a true null hypothesis, which is not related to the p-value. The p-value only tells us how extreme our results are under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true. (C) Not rejecting a null hypothesis when false: This is the definition of a Type II error (? error)—failing to reject a false null hypothesis. The p-value does not measure this, so this option is incorrect. (D) Rejecting a null hypothesis when false: This describes a correct rejection of a false null hypothesis, which is the desired outcome in hypothesis testing. The p-value does not directly indicate whether the null hypothesis is false, only how unusual the observed data is under the assumption that it is true.

questions.text: The risk factor association of smoking with pancreatic cancer was studied in a case control study. The values are: Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B): Since option B is the correct answer, it suggests that Group B has the highest risk association with pancreatic cancer compared to Groups A and C. This means that either: Group B has the highest odds ratio (OR) for pancreatic cancer, OR Statistical analysis showed that Group B had the strongest association compared to A and C. Incorrect Options: (A) Risk is more associated with Group A: Incorrect, because Group A did not show the highest risk based on the study findings. (C) Risk is more associated with Group C: Incorrect, because Group C also had a lower association compared to Group B. (D) Risk is equally associated with all three groups: Incorrect, because if the risk was equal, there would be no significant difference in the odds ratios across the groups, and the correct answer would reflect that.

questions.text: All of the following are true about standard error except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The standard error (SE) measures the variability of a sample statistic (such as the sample mean) from the true population mean. It is calculated as: SE= ?/?n As the sample size (n) increases, the denominator (?n) increases, which makes the SE smaller, not larger. This means that larger sample sizes provide more precise estimates of the population parameter, reducing the standard error. Since standard error decreases as sample size increases, the statement in option (A) is incorrect, making it the correct choice for this question. Incorrect Options: (B) Based on normal distribution: The standard error is closely related to the normal distribution. According to the Central Limit Theorem (CLT), for large enough sample sizes, the sampling distribution of the mean approaches a normal distribution, regardless of the population's original distribution. Therefore, SE is based on normal distribution principles. (C) It depends on the standard deviation of the mean: The standard error is directly dependent on the population standard deviation (?) because it is part of the formula: SE= ?/?n If the population standard deviation is large, the SE will also be larger, meaning greater variability in sample means. (D) Is used to estimate confidence limits: Confidence intervals (CIs) are calculated using the standard error. The formula for a confidence interval is: CI=X?±(Z×SE) where Z is the Z-score for the desired confidence level (e.g., 1.96 for 95% CI). Since standard error is used to determine confidence limits, this statement is true.

questions.text: P- value is defined as :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) "Probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present." A p-value represents the probability of obtaining the observed data (or something more extreme) if the null hypothesis is true. It helps assess the strength of evidence against the null hypothesis. If the p-value is small (e.g., < 0.05), we reject the null hypothesis and conclude that a significant difference exists. However, when we reject the null hypothesis but it is actually true, we make a Type I error (false positive). Since a p-value represents the probability of making a Type I error, it matches option (A), which describes the probability of wrongly declaring a significant difference when there is none. Explanation of Incorrect Options: (B) Probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is present: - Incorrect. This describes a correct rejection of a false null hypothesis, which is not what the p-value represents. The p-value does not measure the probability that a real difference exists; it only tells us how likely our results are under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true. (C) Probability of not declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present: - Incorrect. This describes the correct acceptance of a true null hypothesis, which is unrelated to the p-value. (D) Probability of not declaring a significant difference when actually it is present: - Incorrect. This describes a Type II error (false negative, β error)—failing to reject a false null hypothesis. The p-value does not measure Type II errors; instead, it is linked to Type I errors.

questions.text: A 95% confidence interval for prevalence of cancer in smokers aged > 65 year is 56% to 76%, the chance that the prevalence could be less than 56% is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 2.5%. A 95% confidence interval (CI) of 56% to 76% means that if we were to repeat the study many times, 95% of the calculated confidence intervals would contain the true prevalence of cancer in smokers aged >65 years. A 95% confidence interval means that 5% of the time, the true prevalence could lie outside this range. Since the confidence interval is symmetric, the remaining 5% is split equally on both ends: 2.5% chance that the true prevalence is below 56% 2.5% chance that the true prevalence is above 76% Thus, the probability that the prevalence is actually less than 56% is 2.5%, making option (C) correct. Incorrect Options: (A) Practically Nil: Incorrect. While 2.5% is a small probability, it is not zero. There is still a small chance that the prevalence is below 56%, so this option is incorrect. (B) 44%: Incorrect. This option is misleading. The confidence interval represents a range, not a probability distribution. The probability that the true prevalence is outside the CI is only 5% (2.5?low 56% and 2.5?ove 76%), not 44%. (D) 5%: Incorrect. While 5% of values lie outside the confidence interval, this includes both ends (below 56% and above 76%). Since we are only concerned with values below 56%, the correct probability is 2.5%, not 5%.

questions.text: When we say that “the difference is significant” it mean that :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) "It is unlikely by chance and when p 0.05" Incorrect. If p > 0.05, we fail to reject the null hypothesis, meaning we do not have enough evidence to conclude a significant difference. However, this does not mean the observed difference is "likely by chance"; it just means we lack strong statistical evidence. (B) "It is unlikely by chance and when p > 0.05" Incorrect. A p-value greater than 0.05 does not indicate that the difference is unlikely due to chance; rather, it suggests that the difference could reasonably be explained by random variation. (D) "It is likely by chance and when P < 0.05" Incorrect. If p < 0.05, the difference is considered unlikely due to chance, meaning it is statistically significant. This statement contradicts the correct interpretation of p-values.

questions.text: In a test of significance , P value is 0.023 the observed difference in study can be considered as :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) P value < 0.05 is significant which means null hypothesis is rejected and study accepted Incorrect Options: (A) "Null hypothesis accepted and the study is rejected." Since p = 0.023 < 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis, not accept it. Also, rejecting the study itself is incorrect because the observed difference is statistically significant. (C) "Null hypothesis accepted and the study is accepted." The null hypothesis is not accepted because the p-value is below the significance threshold (0.05), meaning we have enough evidence to reject it. (D) "Null hypothesis rejected and the study is also rejected." If we reject the null hypothesis, it means the study's findings are statistically significant, so the study itself should be accepted, not rejected.

questions.text: If confidence is increased there:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) "Previously significant data becomes insignificant." Confidence level and statistical significance are inversely related in hypothesis testing. The confidence level represents the probability that the true parameter lies within the confidence interval (CI), while the significance level (?) represents the probability of making a Type I error (false positive). Higher confidence level (e.g., increasing from 95% to 99%) ? Wider confidence interval Wider confidence intervals make it harder to detect statistical significance, meaning that some previously significant results (with p Thus, some previously significant results (p Therefore, option (B) is correct because increasing confidence makes significance harder to achieve, leading to previously significant data becoming insignificant. Incorrect Options: (A) "Previously insignificant data becomes significant." Increasing confidence does not make insignificant data significant; instead, it makes significance harder to achieve by increasing the confidence interval range. (C) "No effect on significance." Increasing confidence widens the confidence interval, which affects significance by making it less likely to detect a significant result. (D) "Any change can happen." The effect of increasing confidence is systematic and predictable—it generally makes previously significant results less likely to remain significant. It does not cause random changes in significance.

questions.text: In a group of 100 people the GFR is 85 ml/ minute with a SD of 25. What is the range for 90% CI?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) "81–89." To calculate the 90% confidence interval (CI) for the estimated GFR, we use the formula: CI=X-±Z × SD/?n where: • X- = sample mean = 85 (GFR) • Z = 1.645 (Z-score for a 90% confidence interval) • SD = 25 (Standard deviation) • n = 100 (Sample size) First, we calculate the standard error (SE) of the mean: SE=SD/?n=25/?100=25/10=2.5 Now, we calculate the confidence interval: CI=85±(1.645×2.5) CI=85±4.1125 CI=(85-4.1125,85+4.1125) CI=(80.8875,89.1125) Rounding to the nearest whole number: CI=81to89 Incorrect Options: (A) 70 – 100: This range is too wide and does not reflect the correct margin of error calculated from the given data. (B) 75 – 95: This range is also too wide compared to the calculated CI. (D) 80 – 90: This range is close, but the calculated confidence interval is more precise and is 81–89, not 80–90.
